[Curl](https://curl.se/) is a command-line tool for transferring data from or to a server, using various protocols like HTTP, FTP, SMTP, and more.
The command line option `--retry-delay` in `curl` is used to specify a time interval. It determines the waiting period before `curl` initiates a retry following a failed transfer due to an error. This interval, initially provided in seconds, is internally converted to milliseconds by multiplying it by 1000.

It was discovered that an integer overflow in the interval calculation could lead to an inaccurate waiting period for the retry process. Meaning a very huge number could be overflown and cut-down to be a very small delay period.

The issue was first reported on the HackerOne platform and was fixed as a non-security bug.
4 years after the fact, a CVE was published without involving Curl's developers, which are security-oriented and triage security issues to the fullest extent.

An [article](https://daniel.haxx.se/blog/2023/08/26/cve-2020-19909-is-everything-that-is-wrong-with-cves/) was published regarding the inaccurate Crticial CVSS score this issue received, even though it's not a security issue.

A command-line that triggers this issue on 64-bit machines:
`curl --retry-delay 18446744073709552`

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: The issue cannot result in a severe impact (such as remote code execution)
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description: The issue can only result in the incorrect calculation of the retry delay and does not have a security impact.

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: The prerequisites for exploiting the issue are extremely unlikely
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description: The issue can be triggered only when `curl` is executed with the `--retry-delay` option, which is highly unlikely to be controlled by an attacker.

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: The issue has a detailed technical explanation published, that can aid in exploit development
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description: HackerOne report contains reproducing steps.

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: The issue has been disputed by the vendor
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description: Curl's developer indicated that this is not a security issue, and disputed the vulnerability, also by publishing an article about it.

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: The issue has multiple mentions in general media
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description: An article regarding the inaccurate CVE Critical CVSS score was published by Curl's developer Daniel Stenberg.

vulnerabilities.summary: libcurl skips the certificate verification for a QUIC connection under certain conditions, when built to use wolfSSL. If told to use an unknown/bad cipher or curve, the error path accidentally skips the verification and returns OK, thus ignoring any certificate problems.

When libcurl is asked to perform automatic gzip decompression of
content-encoded HTTP responses with the `CURLOPT_ACCEPT_ENCODING` option,
**using zlib 1.2.0.3 or older**, an attacker-controlled integer overflow would
make libcurl perform a buffer overflow.

extended_information.short_description: Heap buffer overflow in Curl when compiled with very old versions of zlib may lead to remote code execution when connecting to malicious HTTP servers
extended_information.full_description:
[curl](https://curl.se/) is used in command lines or scripts to transfer data. 

When using with old versions of [zlib](https://zlib.net/) (a data-compression library), curl offers to manually parse gzip headers rather than passing it to zlib as is. It was found that the `gzip_do_write()` function is susceptible to a buffer overflow as a result of an integer overflow. This could lead to remote code execution since the heap buffer overflow is controlled both in size and content. 

Curl supports endlessly large gzip headers, which result in the repeated call for `gzip_do_write()`, incrementing the `z->avail_in` variable, keeping track of the size of the buffer required for the gzip header data. Because there is no limit to the size of the gzip header data, this may result in `z->avail_in` overflowing, leading to the allocation of a buffer much smaller than the data being stored, resulting in a buffer overflow.

The vulnerability is only exploitable when Curl is running with very old versions of zlib (1.2.0.3 or older, which is 21+ years old) and when the `CURLOPT_ACCEPT_ENCODING` option is set to `gzip` (non-default value).

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: The issue can be exploited by attackers over the network
The prerequisites for exploiting the issue are extremely unlikely
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description:
For the vulnerability to be exploitable, the user needs to have libcurl work with zlib version 1.2.0.3 or older, which is 21+ years old.

Furthermore, the user must set the `CURLOPT_ACCEPT_ENCODING` to `gzip`.

In addition, the user must connect to a malicious HTTP server using curl.

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: The issue has an exploit published
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description: The vulnerability has a technical write-up including a working PoC that demonstrates denial of service.

vulnerabilities.summary: When curl is instructed to get content using the metalink feature, and a user name and password are used to download the metalink XML file, those same credentials are then subsequently passed on to each of the servers from which curl will download or try to download the contents from. Often contrary to the user's expectations and intentions and without telling the user it happened.

extended_information.short_description: Unexpected behavior in curl can lead to credential leakage when accessing a remote metalink XML with user credentials.
extended_information.full_description:
[Metalink](https://www.metalinker.org/) is an extensible metadata file format that describes one or more computer files available for download.

When curl accesses a Metalink XML with user credentials, the same credentials will be used to access each of the servers that are specified in the Metalink XML files, which is unexpected behavior. If one of these servers are accessed in a non-secure manner (ex. without TLS) or is attacker-controlled, credential leakage will occur.

An example of a vulnerable curl call -
`curl -u myuser:mypass --metalink https://www.somedomain.com/metalink.xml `

Usage of the Metalink feature is exceedingly rare, and as such [has been completely removed](https://daniel.haxx.se/blog/2021/06/07/bye-bye-metalink-in-curl/) in the latest curl version

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: The issue is trivial to exploit and does not require a published writeup or PoC
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description: An attacker simply needs to sniff network traffic in order to perform this attack

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: The prerequisites for exploiting the issue are extremely unlikely
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description: Usage of the metalink curl flag (`--metalink`) is exceedingly rare, and one of the subsequent accesses would need to be attacker-sniffable. In addition to that, the metalink URL needs to be accessed with some set of credentials in order for the attack to have any impact

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: The impact of exploiting the issue depends on the context of surrounding software. A severe impact such as RCE is not guaranteed.
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description: The set of leaked credentials can lead to varying impacts, depending on which resources can be accessed with them

extended_information.remediation:
##### Development mitigations

Disable Metalink support by compiling curl with `./configure --without-metalink`

vulnerabilities.summary: An improper certificate validation vulnerability exists in curl <v8.1.0 in the way it supports matching of wildcard patterns when listed as "Subject Alternative Name" in TLS server certificates. curl can be built to use its own name matching function for TLS rather than one provided by a TLS library. This private wildcard matching function would match IDN (International Domain Name) hosts incorrectly and could as a result accept patterns that otherwise should mismatch. IDN hostnames are converted to puny code before used for certificate checks. Puny coded names always start with `xn--` and should not be allowed to pattern match, but the wildcard check in curl could still check for `x*`, which would match even though the IDN name most likely contained nothing even resembling an `x`.

extended_information.short_description: Improper certificate pattern matching in curl can lead to authentication bypass.

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: The reported CVSS was either wrongly calculated, downgraded by other vendors, or does not reflect the vulnerability's impact
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description: The official project maintainers assigned a "Low" severity to this vulnerability

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: The issue is trivial to exploit and does not require a published writeup or PoC
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description: An attacker could create a certificate with a partial wildcard in the International Domain Name (IDN) field

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: The issue cannot result in a severe impact (such as remote code execution)
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description:
Certificates issued by Certificate Authorities for the public Internet are not allowed to use "partial" wildcards, thus completely avoiding this issue.

In many circumstances, the control of host names used and the wildcards used in issued certificates are controlled by the same entity, making this unlikely to actually become a problem.

vulnerabilities.summary: A path traversal vulnerability exists in curl <8.0.0 SFTP implementation causes the tilde (~) character to be wrongly replaced when used as a prefix in the first path element, in addition to its intended use as the first element to indicate a path relative to the user's home directory. Attackers can exploit this flaw to bypass filtering or execute arbitrary code by crafting a path like /~2/foo while accessing a server with a specific user.

extended_information.short_description: Incorrect path limitation in curl's SFTP implementation can lead to path traversal when processing a path containing the `~` character.
extended_information.full_description:
[Curl](https://curl.se/) is a command-line tool for transferring data from or to a server, using various protocols like HTTP, FTP, SMTP, and more.
curl's [SFTP implementation](https://everything.curl.dev/usingcurl/scpsftp) includes a special feature for URL paths, whereby using a tilde (`~`) in the first element of a path indicates that it should be relative to the user's home directory. As a result, the Curl_getworkingpath function in libcurl replaces `/~/` with the user's home path.

However, using `/~../` can bypass the path traversal logic in `Curl_getworkingpath` due to the tilde character. This resolves to `/home/user/../` and can allow attackers to access remote system path locations that were not intended to be accessible.

To fully exploit this issue and gain access to other users' home directories and retrieve files, attackers must compromise a highly privileged account.

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: The impact of exploiting the issue depends on the context of surrounding software. A severe impact such as RCE is not guaranteed.
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description: The attacker can only access files for which the compromised user account used to establish the SFTP transfer has been granted permission.

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: The issue cannot result in a severe impact (such as remote code execution)
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description: The path traversal possibilities from this issue are very limited.

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: The issue can be exploited by attackers over the network
The prerequisites for exploiting the issue are extremely unlikely
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description: This issue is very limited as the tilde character should be in the first path element and the user can only access files he has been given permission to access.

vulnerabilities.summary:
When asked to both use a `.netrc` file for credentials and to follow HTTP
redirects, curl could leak the password used for the first host to the
followed-to host under certain circumstances.

This flaw only manifests itself if the netrc file has an entry that matches
the redirect target hostname but the entry either omits just the password or
omits both login and password.

This flaw allows a malicious HTTP server to set "super cookies" in curl that
are then passed back to more origins than what is otherwise allowed or
possible. This allows a site to set cookies that then would get sent to
different and unrelated sites and domains.

It could do this by exploiting a mixed case flaw in curl's function that
verifies a given cookie domain against the Public Suffix List (PSL). For
example a cookie could be set with `domain=co.UK` when the URL used a lower
case hostname `curl.co.uk`, even though `co.uk` is listed as a PSL domain.

libcurl's ASN1 parser has this utf8asn1str() function used for parsing an ASN.1 UTF-8 string. Itcan detect an invalid field and return error. Unfortunately, when doing so it also invokes `free()` on a 4 byte localstack buffer.  Most modern malloc implementations detect this error and immediately abort. Some however accept the input pointer and add that memory to its list of available chunks. This leads to the overwriting of nearby stack memory. The content of the overwrite is decided by the `free()` implementation; likely to be memory pointers and a set of flags.  The most likely outcome of exploting this flaw is a crash, although it cannot be ruled out that more serious results can be had in special circumstances.

extended_information.short_description: A stack buffer use-after-free in libcurl leads to denial of service and possibly to remote code execution when parsing crafted certificates.
extended_information.full_description:
[Curl](https://curl.se/) is a command-line tool for transferring data from or to a server, using various protocols like HTTP, FTP, SMTP, and more.
Libcurl's `ASN.1` parser includes the function `utf8asn1str()`, which is designed to parse `ASN.1` UTF-8 strings which can be found in certificates. In some cases, the function might call free() on a 4-byte local stack buffer which can trigger a stack use after free vulnerability. 

Most malloc implementations identify this mistake and immediately terminate the process. However, some implementations accept the input pointer and add that memory to their list of available chunks. This can result in the overwriting of stack memory. The content that overwrites this memory is determined by the free() implementation, and typically consists of memory pointers and a set of flags.

To exploit this issue, the following steps should be taken:

* The attacker needs to set up a malicious server with a TLS certificate that triggers the invalid `free()`
* An application using libcurl needs to connect to the server and during the `connect()` phase parse the invalid certificate. This causes the stack address to be put into the freelist of the allocator
* The attacker interacts with the client in a way that causes the stack address to be returned by a malloc() call and used to store data from the attacker
* Depending on the stack layout, the attacker will potentially be able to overwrite local variables, pointers, and more.


To successfully exploit this vulnerability, one of the fields in the certificate should be encoded with `UniversalString` which is a special encoding which is not common. Most certificate creation tools such as OpenSSL cannot encode strings to `UniversalString`.
Additionally, the certificate information flag (`CURLINFO_CERTINFO`) must be set. This flag enables Libcurl to gather detailed information about the SSL certificate chain used in a connection, which can be retrieved after a transfer using `curl_easy_getinfo` with the `CURLINFO_CERTINFO` option.

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: The issue can be exploited by attackers over the network
The prerequisites for exploiting the issue are extremely unlikely
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description:
To successfully exploit this vulnerability, one of the fields in the certificate should be encoded with `UniversalString` which is a special encoding, which is not common. Most certificate creation tools such as OpenSSL cannot encode strings to `UniversalString`.
Additionally, the certificate information flag (`CURLINFO_CERTINFO`) must be set. This flag enables Libcurl to gather detailed information about the SSL certificate chain used in a connection, which can be retrieved after a transfer using `curl_easy_getinfo` with the `CURLINFO_CERTINFO` option.

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: The reported CVSS was either wrongly calculated, downgraded by other vendors, or does not reflect the vulnerability's impact
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description: The CVSS score does not take into account the prerequisites to exploit this vulnerability.

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: No high-impact exploit or technical writeup were published, and exploitation of the issue with high impact is either non-trivial or completely unproven
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description: Even though an internal test case of libcurl was published to trigger the issue, no PoC is available. An attacker would need deep knowledge of libcurl to exploit this as well as per-target research.

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: The issue has a detailed technical explanation published, that can aid in exploit development
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description: A high-level write-up is available, including an internal test case that demonstrates denial of service.

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: The impact of exploiting the issue depends on the context of surrounding software. A severe impact such as RCE is not guaranteed.
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description: Most modern systems have mitigations and checks that diminish the possibility of this vulnerability leading to remote code execution, thus resulting only in denial of service.

vulnerabilities.summary:
libcurl would wrongly close the same eventfd file descriptor twice when taking
down a connection channel after having completed a threaded name resolve.

When curl is asked to use HSTS, the expiry time for a subdomain might
overwrite a parent domain's cache entry, making it end sooner or later than
otherwise intended.

This affects curl using applications that enable HSTS and use URLs with the
insecure `HTTP://` scheme and perform transfers with hosts like
`x.example.com` as well as `example.com` where the first host is a subdomain
of the second host.

(The HSTS cache either needs to have been populated manually or there needs to
have been previous HTTPS accesses done as the cache needs to have entries for
the domains involved to trigger this problem.)

When `x.example.com` responds with `Strict-Transport-Security:` headers, this
bug can make the subdomain's expiry timeout *bleed over* and get set for the
parent domain `example.com` in curl's HSTS cache.

The result of a triggered bug is that HTTP accesses to `example.com` get
converted to HTTPS for a different period of time than what was asked for by
the origin server. If `example.com` for example stops supporting HTTPS at its
expiry time, curl might then fail to access `http://example.com` until the
(wrongly set) timeout expires. This bug can also expire the parent's entry
*earlier*, thus making curl inadvertently switch back to insecure HTTP earlier
than otherwise intended.

When curl is instructed to download content using the metalink feature, thecontents is verified against a hash provided in the metalink XML file.The metalink XML file points out to the client how to get the same contentfrom a set of different URLs, potentially hosted by different servers and theclient can then download the file from one or several of them. In a serial orparallel manner.If one of the servers hosting the contents has been breached and the contentsof the specific file on that server is replaced with a modified payload, curlshould detect this when the hash of the file mismatches after a completeddownload. It should remove the contents and instead try getting the contentsfrom another URL. This is not done, and instead such a hash mismatch is onlymentioned in text and the potentially malicious content is kept in the file ondisk.

extended_information.short_description: A partial warning message in curl may lead to malicious file download and unspecified impact when using the metalink feature.
extended_information.full_description:
[Metalink](https://www.metalinker.org/) is an extensible metadata file format that describes one or more computer files available for download.

When using Metalink (`--metalink`), curl performs an additional check when the download ends to determine if the content hash matches the one provided in the Metalink XML file.

In case the content on the servers is replaced by another file and so causes a hash mismatch, curl will detect it, issues a warning but not fail the download.
The user may not notice the warning, and continue using the file as though it was fully trusted.

Usage of the Metalink feature is exceedingly rare, and as such [has been completely removed](https://daniel.haxx.se/blog/2021/06/07/bye-bye-metalink-in-curl/) in the latest curl version

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: The issue is trivial to exploit and does not require a published writeup or PoC
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description: An attacker simply needs to modify a downloaded file, either on the hosting server or on the traffic itself by utilizing a MitM attack

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: The prerequisites for exploiting the issue are extremely unlikely
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description: Usage of the metalink curl flag (`--metalink`) is exceedingly rare

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: The issue cannot result in a severe impact (such as remote code execution)
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description: The distinction between only showing a warning and failing the download completely, is not grave

extended_information.remediation:
##### Development mitigations

Disable Metalink support by compiling curl with `./configure --without-metalink`

vulnerabilities.summary:
This flaw allows an attacker to insert cookies at will into a running program
using libcurl, if the specific series of conditions are met.

libcurl performs transfers. In its API, an application creates "easy handles"
that are the individual handles for single transfers.

libcurl provides a function call that duplicates en easy handle called
[curl_easy_duphandle](https://curl.se/libcurl/c/curl_easy_duphandle.html).

If a transfer has cookies enabled when the handle is duplicated, the
cookie-enable state is also cloned - but without cloning the actual
cookies. If the source handle did not read any cookies from a specific file on
disk, the cloned version of the handle would instead store the file name as
`none` (using the four ASCII letters, no quotes).

Subsequent use of the cloned handle that does not explicitly set a source to
load cookies from would then inadvertently load cookies from a file named
`none` - if such a file exists and is readable in the current directory of the
program using libcurl. And if using the correct file format of course.

extended_information.short_description: Unspecified low-severity vulnerability in libcurl (fix pending)
extended_information.full_description:
[Curl](https://curl.se/) is a command-line tool for transferring data from or to a server, using various protocols like HTTP, FTP, SMTP, and more.
Daniel Stenberg, one of Curl’s core maintainers announced that a forthcoming release of Curl, version 8.4.0, is scheduled to be available one week from that date, on October 11th, 2023 at approximately 06:00 UTC. This release will fix two security vulnerabilities in curl.
One of these vulnerabilities is rated as having low severity - CVE-2023-38546.
As of the current moment, no specific details (such as affected versions) have been released.

While not much is known about CVE-2023-38545 the following has been verified by official sources -
1. CVE-2023-38545 is “the worst security problem found in Curl in a long time”. For reference, the last vulnerability that was given a “High” severity by the Curl project is CVE-2021-22901 that was reported in May 2011.
2. The vulnerability does not affect all users of Curl, the maintainers specifically mentioned “there is still going to be a large chunk of users who will not be affected by these problems” - probably due to attack preconditions of this vulnerability.
3. The vulnerability is rated “High” although the Curl project does theoretically support designating vulnerabilities as “Critical” (this never happened so far). This may be related to the previous point - not all users are affected.
4. There is no API nor ABI change in the coming curl release.

This advisory will be updated on October 11th 2023 as details emerge

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: The issue has multiple mentions in general media
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description: The vulnerability received extensive media coverage due to the popularity of curl and its connection to CVE-2023-38545 (which has high severity)

vulnerabilities.summary:
libcurl's ASN1 parser code has the `GTime2str()` function, used for parsing an
ASN.1 Generalized Time field. If given an syntactically incorrect field, the
parser might end up using -1 for the length of the *time fraction*, leading to
a `strlen()` getting performed on a pointer to a heap buffer area that is not
(purposely) null terminated.

This flaw most likely leads to a crash, but can also lead to heap contents
getting returned to the application when
[CURLINFO_CERTINFO](https://curl.se/libcurl/c/CURLINFO_CERTINFO.html) is used.

libcurl supports *pinning* of the server certificate public key for HTTPS transfers. Due to an omission, this check is not performed when connecting with QUIC for HTTP/3, when the TLS backend is wolfSSL. Documentation says the option works with wolfSSL, failing to specify that it does not for QUIC and HTTP/3. Since pinning makes the transfer succeed if the pin is fine, users could unwittingly connect to an impostor server without noticing.

Due to a mistake in libcurl's WebSocket code, a malicious server can send a
particularly crafted packet which makes libcurl get trapped in an endless
busy-loop.

There is no other way for the application to escape or exit this loop other
than killing the thread/process.

This might be used to DoS libcurl-using application.

When an application tells libcurl it wants to allow HTTP/2 server push, and the amount of received headers for the push surpasses the maximum allowed limit (1000), libcurl aborts the server push. When aborting, libcurl inadvertently does not free all the previously allocated headers and instead leaks the memory.  Further, this error condition fails silently and is therefore not easily detected by an application.

A denial of service vulnerability exists in curl <v8.1.0 in the way libcurl provides several different backends for resolving host names, selected at build time. If it is built to use the synchronous resolver, it allows name resolves to time-out slow operations using `alarm()` and `siglongjmp()`. When doing this, libcurl used a global buffer that was not mutex protected and a multi-threaded application might therefore crash or otherwise misbehave.

libcurl accidentally skips the certificate verification for QUIC connections when connecting to a host specified as an IP address in the URL. Therefore, it does not detect impostors or man-in-the-middle attacks.

When curl is told to use the Certificate Status Request TLS extension, often referred to as OCSP stapling, to verify that the server certificate is valid, it might fail to detect some OCSP problems and instead wrongly consider the response as fine.  If the returned status reports another error than 'revoked' (like for example 'unauthorized') it is not treated as a bad certficate.

An information disclosure vulnerability exists in curl <v8.1.0 when doing HTTP(S) transfers, libcurl might erroneously use the read callback (`CURLOPT_READFUNCTION`) to ask for data to send, even when the `CURLOPT_POSTFIELDS` option has been set, if the same handle previously wasused to issue a `PUT` request which used that callback. This flaw may surprise the application and cause it to misbehave and either send off the wrong data or use memory after free or similar in the second transfer. The problem exists in the logic for a reused handle when it is (expected to be) changed from a PUT to a POST.

extended_information.short_description: Handle reuse in libcurl may lead to context-dependent impact when sending a POST request after a PUT request.

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: The prerequisites for exploiting the issue are extremely unlikely
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description:
This flaw cannot be triggered with the command line tool, it requires using libcurl directly, and specifically calling the `curl_easy_setopt` API with the following flags one after another -
* `CURLOPT_READFUNCTION` - to set up a read callback that supplies data to the following PUT request
* `CURLOPT_PUT / CURLOPT_UPLOAD` - to perform a PUT request
* `CURLOPT_POSTFIELDS` - to (attempt to) supply data for the following POST request
* `CURLOPT_POST` - to perform a POST request (which will erroneously use the read callback previously set)

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: The reported CVSS was either wrongly calculated, downgraded by other vendors, or does not reflect the vulnerability's impact
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description: The official project maintainers assigned a "Low" severity to this vulnerability

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: Exploitation of the issue is only possible when the vulnerable component is used in a specific manner. The attacker has to perform per-target research to determine the vulnerable attack vector
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description: The attacker must find a remote input to the victim application that makes it send a PUT request and subsequently a POST request, using libcurl

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: The impact of exploiting the issue depends on the context of surrounding software. A severe impact such as RCE is not guaranteed.
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description: The impact of the vulnerability depends on the data supplied in the `CURLOPT_READFUNCTION` callback and the `CURLOPT_POSTFIELDS` data parameter. A possible impact is leakage of unintended data, since the callback is used for both the PUT and POST requests unintentionally (instead of just the PUT request)

vulnerabilities.summary:
When asked to use a `.netrc` file for credentials **and** to follow HTTP
redirects, curl could leak the password used for the first host to the
followed-to host under certain circumstances.

This flaw only manifests itself if the netrc file has a `default` entry that
omits both login and password. A rare circumstance.

stack_protect_prologue in cfgexpand.c and stack_protect_epilogue in function.c in GNU Compiler Collection (GCC) 4.1 through 8 (under certain circumstances) generate instruction sequences when targeting ARM targets that spill the address of the stack protector guard, which allows an attacker to bypass the protection of -fstack-protector, -fstack-protector-all, -fstack-protector-strong, and -fstack-protector-explicit against stack overflow by controlling what the stack canary is compared against.

extended_information.short_description: Register spilling in stack_protect_prologue and stack_protect_epilogue in GCC may lead to leakage of the stack canary.
extended_information.full_description:
The GNU Compiler Collection (GCC) is an optimizing compiler produced by the GNU Project supporting various programming languages, hardware architectures and operating systems.

A flaw in functions responsible for protecting the stack against buffer overflow (`stack_protect_prologue` and `stack_protect_epilogue`) generates instruction sequences that may spill the address of the stack protector guard (canary) to memory. Local (or context-dependent) attackers that can read this memory, may be able to bypass the stack protection introduced by `-fstack-protector`, `-fstack-protector-all`, `-fstack-protector-strong`, and `-fstack-protector-explicit` flags. 

The preconditions for this sort of manipulation are undefined. Also, this issue affects the 32-bit ARM architecture only.

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: The issue can only be exploited by an attacker with high privileges
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description: The attacker must be able to (partially) read or write the memory of the vulnerable process

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: The reported CVSS was either wrongly calculated, downgraded by other vendors, or does not reflect the vulnerability's impact
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description: Exploitation of this issue does not directly lead to loss of Confidentiality/Integrity/Availability

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: No high-impact exploit or technical writeup were published, and exploitation of the issue with high impact is either non-trivial or completely unproven
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description: There is no technical writeup that explains the exact scenarios where this vulnerability can be exploited

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: The issue cannot be exploited on its own, and can only be used as part of an attack chain
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description:
This issue only allows an attacker to bypass the stack canary mitigation mechanism.
Even on successful exploitation, a separate stack buffer overflow vulnerability must be employed in order to achieve code execution.

vulnerabilities.summary: The POWER9 backend in GNU Compiler Collection (GCC) before version 10 could optimize multiple calls of the __builtin_darn intrinsic into a single call, thus reducing the entropy of the random number generator. This occurred because a volatile operation was not specified. For example, within a single execution of a program, the output of every __builtin_darn() call may be the same.

extended_information.short_description: The gcc random generator for the POWER9 CPU generates repeating, non-random values.
extended_information.full_description: This vulnerability is in the gcc compiler (and not in libgcc) and is only relevant to code compiled for the [POWER9](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/POWER9) CPU architecture that uses the DARN random generator. GCC implementation that uses the POWER9 hardware random generator, `__builtin_darn()` and `__builtin_darn_raw()`, produces repeated output, as can be seen in the example in the [GCC bug report](https://gcc.gnu.org/bugzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=91481#c0). This issue is in the specific gcc implementation, and not in the POWER9 random generator itself. Note that this vulnerability could exist in images where the gcc binary itself isn't present, but only binaries that were compiled by the vulnerable version for POWER9.

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: The impact of exploiting the issue depends on the context of surrounding software. A severe impact such as RCE is not guaranteed.

vulnerabilities.summary: A heap buffer overflow vulnerability has been identified in thesmooth2() in cmsgamma.c in lcms2-2.16 which allows a remote attacker to cause a denial of service. NOTE: the Supplier disputes this because "this is not exploitable as this function is never called on normal color management, is there only as a helper for low-level programming and investigation."

In libssh2 v1.9.0 and earlier versions, the SSH_MSG_DISCONNECT logic in packet.c has an integer overflow in a bounds check, enabling an attacker to specify an arbitrary (out-of-bounds) offset for a subsequent memory read. A crafted SSH server may be able to disclose sensitive information or cause a denial of service condition on the client system when a user connects to the server.
An issue was discovered in function _libssh2_packet_add in libssh2 1.10.0 allows attackers to access out of bounds memory.

extended_information.short_description: Out-of-bounds read in libssh2 `_libssh2_transport_read` may result in denial of service when using sftp, scp and channel functions.

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: The impact of exploiting the issue depends on the context of surrounding software. A severe impact such as RCE is not guaranteed.
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description: The impact of exploiting the DoS depends on the context of libssh usage. If libssh is used as an SSH client, the security impact of DoS is significantly lower than when using libssh as an SSH server.

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: Exploitation of the issue is only possible when the vulnerable component is used in a specific manner. The attacker has to perform per-target research to determine the vulnerable attack vector
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description:
The victim SSH server or client must call one of the following vulnerable functions -

* `libssh2_sftp_init`
* `libssh2_scp_send64`
* `libssh2_scp_send_ex`
* `libssh2_scp_recv`
* `libssh2_scp_recv2`
* `libssh2_channel_open_ex`
* `libssh2_session_handshake`

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: No high-impact exploit or technical writeup were published, and exploitation of the issue with high impact is either non-trivial or completely unproven
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description:
Exploiting this vulnerability requires an attacker to manipulate `libssh` into a memory allocation that would result in an out-of-bounds read.
Currently there is no known proof-of-concept or technical explanation on how to achieve this.

vulnerabilities.summary: In libssh2 before 1.9.0, kex_method_diffie_hellman_group_exchange_sha256_key_exchange in kex.c has an integer overflow that could lead to an out-of-bounds read in the way packets are read from the server. A remote attacker who compromises a SSH server may be able to disclose sensitive information or cause a denial of service condition on the client system when a user connects to the server. This is related to an _libssh2_check_length mistake, and is different from the various issues fixed in 1.8.1, such as CVE-2019-3855.

In GNU Coreutils through 8.29, chown-core.c in chown and chgrp does not prevent replacement of a plain file with a symlink during use of the POSIX "-R -L" options, which allows local users to modify the ownership of arbitrary files by leveraging a race condition.

A flaw was found in GNU Coreutils. The sort utility's begfield() function is vulnerable to a heap buffer under-read. The program may access memory outside the allocated buffer if a user runs a crafted command using the traditional key format. A malicious input could lead to a crash or leak sensitive data.
chroot in GNU coreutils, when used with --userspec, allows local users to escape to the parent session via a crafted TIOCSTI ioctl call, which pushes characters to the terminal's input buffer.

A flaw was found in PostgreSQL that allows authenticated database users to execute arbitrary code through missing overflow checks during SQL array value modification. This issue exists due to an integer overflow during array modification where a remote user can trigger the overflow by providing specially crafted data. This enables the execution of arbitrary code on the target system, allowing users to write arbitrary bytes to memory and extensively read the server's memory.

extended_information.short_description: An integer overflow in PostgreSQL may lead to remote code execution when modifying arrays.
extended_information.full_description:
[PostgreSQL](https://www.postgresql.org/) is a relational database management system (RDBMS) that uses and extends the SQL language combined with many features that safely store and scale complicated data workloads.

PostgreSQL allows columns of a table to be defined as variable-length multidimensional arrays. These arrays can be extended upon request, by assigning to subscripts outside current array bounds. For example, declaring an array of size 2 and then declaring `arr[100] = 6` will extend the array and fill the missing elements with zero.

It has been discovered that `array_set_element`, the function responsible for extending the array, contains calculations which are vulnerable to integer overflow. The result of these calculations is later used to determine the size of a buffer to be allocated in the heap. This may lead to remote code execution or disclosure of server memory.

An attacker must have authenticated access to the PostgreSQL server in order to exploit this vulnerability.

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: The prerequisites for exploiting the issue are extremely unlikely
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description: An attacker must have authenticated access to the PostgreSQL server in order to exploit this vulnerability.

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: The issue results in a severe impact (such as remote code execution)
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description: The impact of this vulnerability is a remote code execution.

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: The issue has an exploit published
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description: Tests that trigger this issue were published along with the official fix commit.

vulnerabilities.summary: Late privilege drop in REFRESH MATERIALIZED VIEW CONCURRENTLY in PostgreSQL allows an object creator to execute arbitrary SQL functions as the command issuer. The command intends to run SQL functions as the owner of the materialized view, enabling safe refresh of untrusted materialized views. The victim is a superuser or member of one of the attacker's roles. The attack requires luring the victim into running REFRESH MATERIALIZED VIEW CONCURRENTLY on the attacker's materialized view. Versions before PostgreSQL 16.2, 15.6, 14.11, 13.14, and 12.18 are affected.

extended_information.short_description: A design flaw in PostgreSQL's leads to privilege escalation when running `REFRESH MATERIALIZED VIEW CONCURRENTLY` on a crafted materialized view.
extended_information.full_description:
PostgreSQL also known as Postgres, is a free and open-source relational database management system (RDBMS) emphasizing extensibility and SQL compliance. PostgreSQL features transactions with atomicity, consistency, isolation, durability (ACID) properties, automatically updatable views, materialized views, triggers, foreign keys, and stored procedures.

"Materialized Views" are database objects that contain the result of a query. Materialized views are not updated when the table they are applied to is, meaning, the materialized view needs to be refreshed to update the result of the query it holds.

The `REFRESH MATERIALIZED VIEW` statement refreshes the specified view. The `CONCURRENT` option that comes with the statement enables the refresh of the materialized view without locking out concurrent selects on the materialized view.

An attacker can trigger this vulnerability by luring a privileged user to execute the vulnerable statement  `REFRESH MATERIALIZED VIEW CONCURRENT` on his malicious materialized view, thus, running his malicious query as the privileged user.

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: The issue is trivial to exploit and does not require a published writeup or PoC
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description: The attacker needs to create a materialized view using the `CREATE RULE` statement

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: The impact of exploiting the issue depends on the context of surrounding software. A severe impact such as RCE is not guaranteed.
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description: The vulnerability's impact depends on the privileges of the user who is lured to run the vulnerable statement.

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: Exploiting the issue requires the user to interact with the vulnerable software
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description: The attack requires luring the victim into running `REFRESH MATERIALIZED VIEW CONCURRENTLY` on the attacker’s materialized view.

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: The issue can only be exploited by an attacker with high privileges
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description: The attack requires the attacker to be able to create an arbitrary view in a PostgreSQL DB ("object creator" privileges)

vulnerabilities.summary: A memory disclosure vulnerability was found in PostgreSQL that allows remote users to access sensitive information by exploiting certain aggregate function calls with 'unknown'-type arguments. Handling 'unknown'-type values from string literals without type designation can disclose bytes, potentially revealing notable and confidential information. This issue exists due to excessive data output in aggregate function calls, enabling remote users to read some portion of system memory.

IN THE EXTENSION SCRIPT, a SQL Injection vulnerability was found in PostgreSQL if it uses @extowner@, @extschema@, or @extschema:...@ inside a quoting construct (dollar quoting, '', or ""). If an administrator has installed files of a vulnerable, trusted, non-bundled extension, an attacker with database-level CREATE privilege can execute arbitrary code as the bootstrap superuser.

extended_information.short_description: Insufficient filtering in PostgreSQL may lead to SQL injection (as superuser) by authenticated attackers in a non-default configuration.

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: The prerequisites for exploiting the issue are extremely unlikely
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description: An extension script is vulnerable if it uses `@extowner@`, `@extschema@`, or `@extschema:...@` inside a quoting construct (dollar quoting, `'`', or `""`).  To exploit this vulnerability, the database must contain files from a vulnerable extension that an administrator has installed, there are no bundled extensions which are vulnerable to this issue. Additionally, the attacker must possess CREATE privileges at the database level. The attacker must perform per-target research in order to construct a tailored payload.

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: The issue can only be exploited by an attacker with high privileges
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description: The attacker must possess CREATE privileges at the database level.

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: The reported CVSS was either wrongly calculated, downgraded by other vendors, or does not reflect the vulnerability's impact
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description: The CVSS does not take into account the high attack complexity of exploitation (The attacker must perform per-target research in order to construct a tailored payload)

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: The issue is trivial to exploit and does not require a published writeup or PoC
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description: Once the attacker identifies a vulnerable extension script, they can simply write a simple `CREATE` query which will cause SQL injection

vulnerabilities.summary: A flaw was found in PostgreSQL involving the pg_cancel_backend role that signals background workers, including the logical replication launcher, autovacuum workers, and the autovacuum launcher. Successful exploitation requires a non-core extension with a less-resilient background worker and would affect that specific background worker only. This issue may allow a remote high privileged user to launch a denial of service (DoS) attack.

Insufficient validation of filenames against control characters in Apache Subversion repositories served via mod_dav_svn allows authenticated users with commit access to commit a corrupted revision, leading to disruption for users of the repository.

All versions of Subversion up to and including Subversion 1.14.4 are affected if serving repositories via mod_dav_svn. Users are recommended to upgrade to version 1.14.5, which fixes this issue.

Repositories served via other access methods are not affected.

ImageMagick is free and open-source software used for editing and manipulating digital images. Prior to versions 6.9.13-28 and 7.1.2-2, passing a geometry string containing only a colon (":") to montage -geometry leads GetGeometry() to set width/height to 0. Later, ThumbnailImage() divides by these zero dimensions, triggering a crash (SIGFPE/abort), resulting in a denial of service. This issue has been patched in versions 6.9.13-28 and 7.1.2-2.
A heap use-after-free flaw was found in coders/bmp.c in ImageMagick.
ImageMagick 7.0.8-35 has a memory leak in coders/dps.c, as demonstrated by XCreateImage.

The AcquireMagickMemory function in MagickCore/memory.c in ImageMagick 7.0.3.3 before 7.0.3.8 allows remote attackers to have unspecified impact via a crafted image, which triggers a memory allocation failure.  NOTE: this vulnerability exists because of an incomplete fix for CVE-2016-8862.

ImageMagick is free and open-source software used for editing and manipulating digital images. Prior to versions 6.9.13-27 and 7.1.2-1, the magnified size calculations in ReadOneMNGIMage (in coders/png.c) are unsafe and can overflow, leading to memory corruption. This issue has been patched in versions 6.9.13-27 and 7.1.2-1.
The WritePICONImage function in coders/xpm.c in ImageMagick 7.0.6-4 allows remote attackers to cause a denial of service (memory leak) via a crafted file that is mishandled in an OpenPixelCache call.

ImageMagick is free and open-source software used for editing and manipulating digital images. Prior to versions 6.9.13-27 and 7.1.2-1, there is undefined behavior (function-type-mismatch) in splay tree cloning callback. This results in a deterministic abort under UBSan (DoS in sanitizer builds), with no crash in a non-sanitized build. This issue has been patched in versions 6.9.13-27 and 7.1.2-1.

A design flaw in image processing software that modifies JPEG images might not modify the original EXIF thumbnail, which could lead to an information leak of potentially sensitive visual information that had been removed from the main JPEG image.
A vulnerability was found in ImageMagick. This security flaw cause a remote code execution vulnerability in OpenBlob with --enable-pipes configured.

extended_information.short_description: Insufficient input validation in ImageMagick allows attackers to perform command injection when processing files with crafted filenames.
extended_information.full_description: [ImageMagick](https://www.imagemagick.org/), also known as Imagick in PHP, is a free and open-source cross-platform software suite for displaying, creating, converting, modifying, and editing raster images.

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: Exploitation of the issue is only possible when the vulnerable component is used in a specific manner. The attacker has to perform per-target research to determine the vulnerable attack vector
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description:
The attacker must find remote input that can propagate into the processed image's file name.
For example -
```
magick '|cat test.txt > /tmp/leak|< logo.jpg' info:
```

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: The issue has an exploit published
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description: PoC demonstrates command execution

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: The prerequisites for exploiting the issue are extremely unlikely
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description:
For the instance to be vulnerable, ImageMagick has to be built with the following (non-default) compile-time flag -
```
./configure --enable-pipes
```

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: The issue has been disputed by the vendor
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description: The maintainers claim this "issue" is a feature, not a bug. Moreover, they reverted the initial patch for this vulnerability.

vulnerabilities.summary: ImageMagick is free and open-source software used for editing and manipulating digital images. Versions prior to 7.1.2-0 and 6.9.13-26 have a heap buffer overflow in the `InterpretImageFilename` function. The issue stems from an off-by-one error that causes out-of-bounds memory access when processing format strings containing consecutive percent signs (`%%`). Versions 7.1.2-0 and 6.9.13-26 fix the issue.

extended_information.short_description: Off-by-one heap overread in ImageMagic leads to partial denial of service when accepting a crafted filename in the command line arguments

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: The reported CVSS was either wrongly calculated, downgraded by other vendors, or does not reflect the vulnerability's impact
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description: NVD CVSS is critical since the vulnerability is wrongly considered as a heap buffer overwrite. However, the vulnerability is a (off-by-one) heap buffer overread, which cannot lead to significant security impact.

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: The issue cannot result in a severe impact (such as remote code execution)
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description: In the worst case, the vulnerability could lead to crashing the ImageMagick forked CLI process. Crashing a forked process has no significant security impact.

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: The issue is trivial to exploit and does not require a published writeup or PoC
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description: An attacker can simply provide an input filename that ends with `%%` to trigger the vulnerability

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: The prerequisites for exploiting the issue are extremely unlikely
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description: The vulnerability requires an attacker to control the suffix of the input file to the `magick` tool. For example - `magick foo%% out.img`. The suffix of the input file is usually not externally-controlled. In addition, even when the vulnerability is triggered, an off-by-one read will only cause a DoS under rare circumstances which are usually not attacker-controlled.

vulnerabilities.summary: ImageMagick is free and open-source software used for editing and manipulating digital images. Prior to version 7.1.2-1, when preparing to transform from Log to sRGB colorspaces, the logmap construction fails to handle cases where the reference-black or reference-white value is larger than 1024. This leads to corrupting memory beyond the end of the allocated logmap buffer. This issue has been patched in version 7.1.2-1.

ImageMagick is free and open-source software used for editing and manipulating digital images. In versions prior to 7.1.2-0 and 6.9.13-26, in ImageMagick's `magick mogrify` command, specifying multiple consecutive `%d` format specifiers in a filename template causes internal pointer arithmetic to generate an address below the beginning of the stack buffer, resulting in a stack overflow through `vsnprintf()`. Versions 7.1.2-0 and 6.9.13-26 fix the issue.

In ImageMagick 7.0.8-11 Q16, a tiny input file 0x50 0x36 0x36 0x36 0x36 0x4c 0x36 0x38 0x36 0x36 0x36 0x36 0x36 0x36 0x1f 0x35 0x50 0x00 can result in a hang of several minutes during which CPU and memory resources are consumed until ultimately an attempted large memory allocation fails. Remote attackers could leverage this vulnerability to cause a denial of service via a crafted file.
A vulnerability was found in ImageMagick. This security flaw ouccers as an undefined behaviors of casting double to size_t in svg, mvg and other coders (recurring bugs of CVE-2022-32546).

In WriteOnePNGImage() of the PNG coder at coders/png.c, an improper call to AcquireVirtualMemory() and memset() allows for an out-of-bounds write later when PopShortPixel() from MagickCore/quantum-private.h is called. The patch fixes the calls by adding 256 to rowbytes. An attacker who is able to supply a specially crafted image could affect availability with a low impact to data integrity. This flaw affects ImageMagick versions prior to 6.9.10-68 and 7.0.8-68.

ImageMagick is free and open-source software used for editing and manipulating digital images. Prior to version 7.1.2-1, ImageMagick is vulnerable to heap-buffer overflow read around the handling of images with separate alpha channels when performing image magnification in ReadOneMNGIMage. This can likely be used to leak subsequent memory contents into the output image. This issue has been patched in version 7.1.2-1.
In MIFF image processing in ImageMagick before 7.1.1-44, image depth is mishandled after SetQuantumFormat is used.

The WritePICONImage function in coders/xpm.c in ImageMagick 7.0.6-4 allows remote attackers to cause a denial of service (memory leak) via a crafted file that is mishandled in an AcquireSemaphoreInfo call.

in SetImageExtent() of /MagickCore/image.c, an incorrect image depth size can cause a memory leak because the code which checks for the proper image depth size does not reset the size in the event there is an invalid size. The patch resets the depth to a proper size before throwing an exception. The memory leak can be triggered by a crafted input file that is processed by ImageMagick and could cause an impact to application reliability, such as denial of service. This flaw affects ImageMagick versions prior to 7.0.9-0.

ImageMagick is free and open-source software used for editing and manipulating digital images. In versions prior to 7.1.2-0, infinite lines occur when writing during a specific XMP file conversion command. Version 7.1.2-0 fixes the issue.

extended_information.short_description: Infinite loop in ImageMagick may lead to denial of service when parsing crafted image files.
extended_information.full_description:
[ImageMagick](https://imagemagick.org/index.php) is a free, open-source software suite used for editing and manipulating digital images.

`GetXmpNumeratorAndDenominator()` is a utility function in ImageMagick that is responsible for the conversion of [xmp](https://www.adobe.com/products/xmp.html) metadata saved in decimals to simple fractions to keep accuracy and avoid rounding errors.

The algorithm responsible for the calculation of the numerator and denominator of the resulting simple fraction checks the accuracy of the conversion by checking for `while(fabs(df-value) > MagickEpsilon)
` where `df` is the calculated simple fraction, `value` is the decimal value, and `MagickEpsilon` is a minimal value (`1.0e-12`).

The algorithm doesn't take into consideration cases where the decimal value represents an irrational fraction, resulting in `df` oscillating around `value`. This causes the while loop to never resolve, leading to the program becoming stuck in an infinite loop.

The vulnerability can be triggered by regular usage of the `magick` CLI tool, for example - `magick evil.img output.img`

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: Exploitation of the issue is only possible when the vulnerable component is used in a specific manner. The attacker has to perform per-target research to determine the vulnerable attack vector
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description: In order to exploit the vulnerability, a potential attacker needs to parse a maliciously crafted file via the ImageMagick library or the magick CLI tool.

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: The issue has an exploit published
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description: The vulnerability has a published POC, demonstrating denial of service when parsing a maliciously crafted file via the magick CLI tool.

vulnerabilities.summary: A memory leak in ImageMagick 7.0.10-45 and 6.9.11-22 allows remote attackers to perform a denial of service via the "identify -help" command.

extended_information.short_description: (Non-Issue) A design problem in ImageMagick may lead to denial of service when using the help argument.

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: The reported CVSS was either wrongly calculated, downgraded by other vendors, or does not reflect the vulnerability's impact
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description: The CVSS does not reflect the prerequisites to trigger the vulnerability.

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: The prerequisites for exploiting the issue are extremely unlikely
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description: The ImageMagick `identify` command must be run with the '-help' argument.

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: The issue cannot result in a severe impact (such as remote code execution)
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description: This vulnerability has no security impact since the triggered memory leak is only caused by not freeing-up objects from the memory, which are freed anyway when the process exits, just after printing the help menu.

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: The issue has an exploit published
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description: A PoC has been published along with the original report. The vulnerable command-line is: `identify -help`

vulnerabilities.summary: ImageMagick is free and open-source software used for editing and manipulating digital images. In versions prior to 7.1.2-0 and 6.9.13-26, in ImageMagick's `magick stream` command, specifying multiple consecutive `%d` format specifiers in a filename template causes a memory leak. Versions 7.1.2-0 and 6.9.13-26 fix the issue.
In multispectral MIFF image processing in ImageMagick before 7.1.1-44, packet_size is mishandled (related to the rendering of all channels in an arbitrary order).

There are several memory leaks in the MIFF coder in /coders/miff.c due to improper image depth values, which can be triggered by a specially crafted input file. These leaks could potentially lead to an impact to application availability or cause a denial of service. It was originally reported that the issues were in `AcquireMagickMemory()` because that is where LeakSanitizer detected the leaks, but the patch resolves issues in the MIFF coder, which incorrectly handles data being passed to `AcquireMagickMemory()`. This flaw affects ImageMagick versions prior to 7.0.9-0.

A vulnerability was discovered in ImageMagick where a specially created SVG file loads itself and causes a segmentation fault. This flaw allows a remote attacker to pass a specially crafted SVG file that leads to a segmentation fault, generating many trash files in "/tmp," resulting in a denial of service. When ImageMagick crashes, it generates a lot of trash files. These trash files can be large if the SVG file contains many render actions. In a denial of service attack, if a remote attacker uploads an SVG file of size t, ImageMagick generates files of size 103*t. If an attacker uploads a 100M SVG, the server will generate about 10G.

Multiple unspecified vulnerabilities in GraphicsMagick before 1.2.4 allow remote attackers to cause a denial of service (crash, infinite loop, or memory consumption) via (a) unspecified vectors in the (1) AVI, (2) AVS, (3) DCM, (4) EPT, (5) FITS, (6) MTV, (7) PALM, (8) RLA, and (9) TGA decoder readers; and (b) the GetImageCharacteristics function in magick/image.c, as reachable from a crafted (10) PNG, (11) JPEG, (12) BMP, or (13) TIFF file.

The ReadPCXImage function in coders/pcx.c in ImageMagick 7.0.4.9 allows remote attackers to cause a denial of service (attempted large memory allocation and application crash) via a crafted file. NOTE: this vulnerability exists because of an incomplete fix for CVE-2016-8862 and CVE-2016-8866.

ImageMagick is free and open-source software used for editing and manipulating digital images. Prior to ImageMagick versions 6.9.13-28 and 7.1.2-2, a format string bug vulnerability exists in InterpretImageFilename function where user input is directly passed to FormatLocaleString without proper sanitization. An attacker can overwrite arbitrary memory regions, enabling a wide range of attacks from heap overflow to remote code execution. This issue has been patched in versions 6.9.13-28 and 7.1.2-2.

The IsPixelMonochrome function in MagickCore/pixel-accessor.h in ImageMagick 7.0.3.0 allows remote attackers to cause a denial of service (out-of-bounds read and crash) via a crafted file.  NOTE: the vendor says "This is a Q64 issue and we do not support Q64."

A flaw was found in ImageMagick in MagickCore/quantum-private.h. An attacker who submits a crafted file that is processed by ImageMagick could trigger a heap buffer overflow. This would most likely lead to an impact to application availability, but could potentially lead to an impact to data integrity as well. This flaw affects ImageMagick versions prior to 7.0.9-0.

A flaw was found in ImageMagick in versions before 7.0.11, where a division by zero in sRGBTransformImage() in the MagickCore/colorspace.c may trigger undefined behavior via a crafted image file that is submitted by an attacker processed by an application using ImageMagick. The highest threat from this vulnerability is to system availability.

ImageMagick is free and open-source software used for editing and manipulating digital images. Prior to versions 6.9.13-28 and 7.1.2-2 for ImageMagick's 32-bit build, a 32-bit integer overflow in the BMP encoder’s scanline-stride computation collapses bytes_per_line (stride) to a tiny value while the per-row writer still emits 3 × width bytes for 24-bpp images. The row base pointer advances using the (overflowed) stride, so the first row immediately writes past its slot and into adjacent heap memory with attacker-controlled bytes. This is a classic, powerful primitive for heap corruption in common auto-convert pipelines. This issue has been patched in versions 6.9.13-28 and 7.1.2-2.
ImageMagick 7.0.8-50 Q16 has memory leaks at AcquireMagickMemory because of an error in MagickWand/mogrify.c.

A flaw exists in gdk‑pixbuf within the gdk_pixbuf__jpeg_image_load_increment function (io-jpeg.c) and in glib’s g_base64_encode_step (glib/gbase64.c). When processing maliciously crafted JPEG images, a heap buffer overflow can occur during Base64 encoding, allowing out-of-bounds reads from heap memory, potentially causing application crashes or arbitrary code execution.

In GNOME GdkPixbuf (aka gdk-pixbuf) through 2.42.10, the ANI (Windows animated cursor) decoder encounters heap memory corruption (in ani_load_chunk in io-ani.c) when parsing chunks in a crafted .ani file. A crafted file could allow an attacker to overwrite heap metadata, leading to a denial of service or code execution attack. This occurs in gdk_pixbuf_set_option() in gdk-pixbuf.c.

extended_information.short_description: Heap buffer overflow in GDK-Pixbuf may lead to remote code execution when parsing a crafted `.ani` image.
extended_information.full_description:
GDK-Pixbuf is a library that loads image data in various formats and stores it as linear buffers in memory. The buffers can then be scaled, composited, modified, saved, or rendered.

GDK-Pixbuf can load image data encoded in different formats, such as PNG, JPEG, TIFF, and ANI.

A heap buffer overflow vulnerability was discovered, which can be triggered by attackers when the victim uses the vulnerable functions [1] with user-supplied input. The input should be a path to a crafted `.ani` image that can crash the program or lead to remote code execution.

The issue lies in a loop condition that is solely based on the value of a variable called `context->pos`, which might not accurately reflect the number of valid elements in the `context->animation->pixbufs[]` array that it loops through, leading to accessing memory that may not belong to the array, resulting in undefined behavior, such as memory corruption.

There is currently no patch to this vulnerability.

[1] `gdk_pixbuf_animation_new_from_file`, `gdk_pixbuf_animation_new_from_resource`, `gdk_pixbuf_animation_new_from_stream`, `gdk_pixbuf_new_from_file`, `gdk_pixbuf_new_from_file_at_size`, `gdk_pixbuf_new_from_file_at_scale`.

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: The issue has an exploit published
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description: While no PoC RCE exploit is available, a crashing PoC is available. Heap buffer overflows can often be exploited for remote code execution.

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: The issue results in a severe impact (such as remote code execution)
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description: Potential remote code execution

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: Exploitation of the issue is only possible when the vulnerable component is used in a specific manner. The attacker has to perform per-target research to determine the vulnerable attack vector
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description:
The attacker must be able to upload an `.ani` file which will be parsed by any of the following APIs -

* `gdk_pixbuf_animation_new_from_file`
* `gdk_pixbuf_animation_new_from_resource`
* `gdk_pixbuf_animation_new_from_stream`
* `gdk_pixbuf_new_from_file`
* `gdk_pixbuf_new_from_file_at_size`
* `gdk_pixbuf_new_from_file_at_scale`.

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: The issue has a detailed technical explanation published, that can aid in exploit development

extended_information.remediation:
##### Deployment mitigations

Delete the library that implements the vulnerable animated loader - `libpixbufloader-ani.so`

vulnerabilities.summary: A flaw was found in the GIF parser of GdkPixbuf’s LZW decoder. When an invalid symbol is encountered during decompression, the decoder sets the reported output size to the full buffer length rather than the actual number of written bytes. This logic error results in uninitialized sections of the buffer being included in the output, potentially leaking arbitrary memory contents in the processed image.

node-tar is a Tar for Node.js. node-tar prior to version 6.2.1 has no limit on the number of sub-folders created in the folder creation process. An attacker who generates a large number of sub-folders can consume memory on the system running node-tar and even crash the Node.js client within few seconds of running it using a path with too many sub-folders inside. Version 6.2.1 fixes this issue by preventing extraction in excessively deep sub-folders.
An issue in Academy Software Foundation openexr v.3.2.3 and before allows a local attacker to cause a denial of service (DoS) via the convert function of exrmultipart.cpp.

OpenEXR provides the specification and reference implementation of the EXR file format, an image storage format for the motion picture industry. In version 3.3.2, applications trust unvalidated dataWindow size values from file headers, which can lead to excessive memory allocation and performance degradation when processing malicious files. This is fixed in version 3.3.3.

A flaw was found in OpenEXR's hufDecode functionality. This flaw allows an attacker who can pass a crafted file to be processed by OpenEXR, to trigger an undefined right shift error. The highest threat from this vulnerability is to system availability.
An integer overflow leading to a heap-buffer overflow was found in OpenEXR in versions before 3.0.1. An attacker could use this flaw to crash an application compiled with OpenEXR.

Header::readfrom in IlmImf/ImfHeader.cpp in OpenEXR 2.2.0 allows remote attackers to cause a denial of service (excessive memory allocation) via a crafted file that is accessed with the ImfOpenInputFile function in IlmImf/ImfCRgbaFile.cpp. NOTE: The maintainer and multiple third parties believe that this vulnerability isn't valid
OpenEXR 2.3.0 has a memory leak in ThreadPool in IlmBase/IlmThread/IlmThreadPool.cpp, as demonstrated by exrmultiview.
An issue was discovered in compare_digest in Lib/hmac.py in Python through 3.9.1. Constant-time-defeating optimisations were possible in the accumulator variable in hmac.compare_digest.

extended_information.short_description: Non-constant-time comparison in Python hmac.compare_digest can lead to timing attacks.

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: The issue can only be exploited by an attacker that can execute code on the vulnerable machine (excluding exceedingly rare circumstances)
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description: The attacker must be able to perform a side-channel timing attack on the Python app, this is much more likely to be possible with an attacker running on the same machine as the vulnerable Python app

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: The issue is trivial to exploit and does not require a published writeup or PoC
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description: The attacker must mount a timing attack on the Python app using `hmac.compare_digest`, no special exploit knowledge is needed

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: The impact of exploiting the issue depends on the context of surrounding software. A severe impact such as RCE is not guaranteed.
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description: The security impact of exploiting the vulnerability depends on the access granted to the attacker by breaking the HMAC comparison.

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: Exploitation of the issue is only possible when the vulnerable component is used in a specific manner. The attacker has to perform per-target research to determine the vulnerable attack vector
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description: The vulnerable Python app must call `hmac.compare_digest`. In addition, the attacker must be able to perform a side-channel timing attack on the Python app.

vulnerabilities.summary: An XML External Entity (XXE) issue was discovered in Python through 3.9.1. The plistlib module no longer accepts entity declarations in XML plist files to avoid XML vulnerabilities.

extended_information.short_description: XXE in Python plistlib can lead to data leakage and DoS when parsing crafted plist data.

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: The issue is trivial to exploit and does not require a published writeup or PoC
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description:
The attacker can simply supply a PLIST containing XML External Entities, for example - 
```xml
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
<!DOCTYPE plist PUBLIC "-//Apple//DTD PLIST 1.0//EN" "http://www.apple.com/DTDs/PropertyList-1.0.dtd" [
   <!ENTITY entity "replacement text">
  ]>
<plist version="1.0">
  <dict>
    <key>A</key>
    <string>&entity;</string>
  </dict>
</plist>
```

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: The reported CVSS was either wrongly calculated, downgraded by other vendors, or does not reflect the vulnerability's impact
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description: The critical CVSS given to this issue does not take into account the high attack complexity and per-target research needed to exploit this issue

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: Exploitation of the issue is only possible when the vulnerable component is used in a specific manner. The attacker has to perform per-target research to determine the vulnerable attack vector
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description: The attacker must find remote input that propagates to the `plistlib.load` or `plistlib.loads` API calls

vulnerabilities.summary: A flaw was found in Python, specifically within the urllib.parse module. This module helps break Uniform Resource Locator (URL) strings into components. The issue involves how the urlparse method does not sanitize input and allows characters like '\r' and '\n' in the URL path. This flaw allows an attacker to input a crafted URL, leading to injection attacks. This flaw affects Python versions prior to 3.10.0b1, 3.9.5, 3.8.11, 3.7.11 and 3.6.14.

extended_information.short_description: Improper URL parsing in Python can lead to filter bypass when comparing the URL's scheme.
extended_information.full_description:
The `urllib` package in Python is a built-in module that provides a set of functions for working with URLs (Uniform Resource Locators). It offers capabilities for making HTTP requests, handling URL encodings, parsing URLs, and other common tasks related to web interactions.

The `urllib.parse` module, part of the `urllib` package in Python, provides functions for parsing and manipulating URLs. It offers utilities for URL encoding and decoding, splitting URLs into components, constructing URLs from components, and other URL-related operations.

The `urlparse()` or `urlsplit()` functions have been found to have a flaw during URL processing. This vulnerability allows an attacker to pass an invalid URL that contains newlines and tabs without undergoing proper sanitation.
This violates the URL Specification, which mandates the removal of all newlines and tabs from a URL prior to processing.

The issue could cause any blacklisting methods based on the parsed URL to fail.

An example where the URL path is not parsed correctly -
```py
from urllib.parse import urlsplit

splitresult = urlsplit("fi\nle://127.0.0.1/etc/passwd")
print(splitresult)
```

The result would be:
```
SplitResult(scheme='', netloc='', path="fi\nle://127.0.0.1/etc/passwd", query='', fragment='')
```

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: The issue can be exploited by attackers over the network
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description: It is common to use this library for parsing URLs that are provided by remote users.

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: The impact of exploiting the issue depends on the context of surrounding software. A severe impact such as RCE is not guaranteed.
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description: The security impact of this issue depends on what is done with the parsed URL. If the parsed URL is compared to a blacklist in order to deny specific operations, there may be a security impact when exploiting this issue.

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: Exploitation of the issue is only possible when the vulnerable component is used in a specific manner. The attacker has to perform per-target research to determine the vulnerable attack vector
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description: An attacker must find a remote input that propagates to the `urlparse()` function.

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: The issue is trivial to exploit and does not require a published writeup or PoC
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description: The vulnerability can be easily triggered by adding newline or tab characters to the parsed URL.

vulnerabilities.summary: An issue was discovered in Python before 3.8.18, 3.9.x before 3.9.18, 3.10.x before 3.10.13, and 3.11.x before 3.11.5. It primarily affects servers (such as HTTP servers) that use TLS client authentication. If a TLS server-side socket is created, receives data into the socket buffer, and then is closed quickly, there is a brief window where the SSLSocket instance will detect the socket as "not connected" and won't initiate a handshake, but buffered data will still be readable from the socket buffer. This data will not be authenticated if the server-side TLS peer is expecting client certificate authentication, and is indistinguishable from valid TLS stream data. Data is limited in size to the amount that will fit in the buffer. (The TLS connection cannot directly be used for data exfiltration because the vulnerable code path requires that the connection be closed on initialization of the SSLSocket.)

The package python/cpython from 0 and before 3.6.13, from 3.7.0 and before 3.7.10, from 3.8.0 and before 3.8.8, from 3.9.0 and before 3.9.2 are vulnerable to Web Cache Poisoning via urllib.parse.parse_qsl and urllib.parse.parse_qs by using a vector called parameter cloaking. When the attacker can separate query parameters using a semicolon (;), they can cause a difference in the interpretation of the request between the proxy (running with default configuration) and the server.
