jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description: The vulnerability received extensive media coverage from Google, Cloudflare, and more.

vulnerabilities.summary: nghttp2 is an implementation of the Hypertext Transfer Protocol version 2 in C. The nghttp2 library prior to version 1.61.0 keeps reading the unbounded number of HTTP/2 CONTINUATION frames even after a stream is reset to keep HPACK context in sync.  This causes excessive CPU usage to decode HPACK stream. nghttp2 v1.61.0 mitigates this vulnerability by limiting the number of CONTINUATION frames it accepts per stream. There is no workaround for this vulnerability.

extended_information.short_description: A design problem in the implementation of the HTTP/2 protocol in Nghttp2 may lead to denial of service by abusing frame flags.
extended_information.full_description:
[Nghttp2](https://github.com/nghttp2/nghttp2) is an open-source implementation of HTTP/2, a significant upgrade to the HTTP protocol, offering improved efficiency and performance for web communication. It provides libraries and command-line tools for developers to integrate HTTP/2 features into their applications, including binary framing, header compression, multiplexing of requests, and server push. `Nghttp2` is widely used in various projects, such as web servers, proxies, and clients.

`HTTP/2` is a binary protocol where the client and server exchange binary frames instead of text lines as in `HTTP/1.x`. `HTTP/2` resolves numerous concerns found in HTTP/1.1 by organizing each HTTP message into a series of HTTP/2 frames. These frames include frame type, length, flags, stream identifier (ID), and payload.

The `HEADERS` frame type allows sending HTTP headers of, both, request and response. The `HEADERS` frame contains many flags.
The `CONTINUATION` frame type is similar to the `HEADER` frame, but it has just one flag: `END_HEADERS`. When it is not set, the peer knows that more headers are coming in the following `CONTINUATION` frames.

This mechanism allows an attacker to send an `HTTP/2` stream with `CONTINUATION` frames, without setting the `END_HEADERS` flag in any of the frames. This can cause denial-of-service when sending an excessive number of these crafted frames due to caching all frames in memory.

The issue is exploitable by default due to `Nghttp2` being an `HTTP/2`-only implementation.

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: The prerequisites for exploiting the issue are either extremely common or nonexistent (always exploitable)
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description: Nghttp2 is vulnerable in its default configuration.

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: The issue has a detailed technical explanation published, that can aid in exploit development
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description: A very detailed technical write-up has been published regarding the issue.

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: The issue results in a severe impact (such as remote code execution)
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description: This issue can lead to denial of service.

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: The issue can be exploited by attackers over the network
The issue has multiple mentions in general media
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description: This issue is related to the well-covered attack "HTTP/2 CONTINUATION Flood".

vulnerabilities.summary: In nghttp2 before version 1.41.0, the overly large HTTP/2 SETTINGS frame payload causes denial of service. The proof of concept attack involves a malicious client constructing a SETTINGS frame with a length of 14,400 bytes (2400 individual settings entries) over and over again. The attack causes the CPU to spike at 100%. nghttp2 v1.41.0 fixes this vulnerability. There is a workaround to this vulnerability. Implement nghttp2_on_frame_recv_callback callback, and if received frame is SETTINGS frame and the number of settings entries are large (e.g., > 32), then drop the connection.

GNOME librsvg version before commit c6ddf2ed4d768fd88adbea2b63f575cd523022ea contains a Improper input validation vulnerability in rsvg-io.c that can result in the victim's Windows username and NTLM password hash being leaked to remote attackers through SMB. This attack appear to be exploitable via The victim must process a specially crafted SVG file containing an UNC path on Windows.
An out-of-bounds read/write vulnerability was found in e2fsprogs 1.46.5. This issue leads to a segmentation fault and possibly arbitrary code execution via a specially crafted filesystem.

extended_information.short_description: An out-of-bounds write in e2fsck can lead to local privilege escalation when processing a crafted filesystem image.
extended_information.full_description:
[e2fsprogs](http://e2fsprogs.sourceforge.net/) is a set of utilities for maintaining the ext2, ext3 and ext4 file systems. Since those file systems are often the default for Linux distributions, it is commonly considered to be essential software.

A crafted malicious filesystem can cause a segmentation fault and arbitrary code execution in e2fsprogs. 

However, the attacker should either find an input that propagates and turns out to be passed to the `e2fsck` tool or use another vulnerability to upload the malicious filesystem image and find a way to pass it to `e2fsck`.

It’s highly unlikely a remote service would use the `e2fsck` tool on externally supplied input.

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: The issue can only be exploited by an attacker that can execute code on the vulnerable machine (excluding exceedingly rare circumstances)
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description: The attack must be performed locally, as it’s highly unlikely a remote service would use the `e2fsck` tool on externally supplied input.

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: The issue cannot result in a severe impact (such as remote code execution)
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description: The Denial-of-Service impact is mitigated since the only known attack vector is by running a forked process (`e2fsck`). Crashing a forked client process is usually not a severe impact. Also, the e2fsprogs tools are userland utilities, thus not affecting the kernel and cannot lead to a container escape.

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: The prerequisites for exploiting the issue are extremely unlikely
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description: The attacker must be able to put a crafted filesystem image on the target filesystem and have a privileged user execute the `e2fsck` tool on this image.

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: The issue has an exploit published
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description: A Proof-of-Concept which leads to a Denial-of-Service was published by the reporting researcher.

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: Exploiting the issue requires the user to interact with the vulnerable software
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description: Requires the user to run the `e2fsck` tool on a crafted filesystem.

vulnerabilities.summary: GNU Wget is vulnerable to an SSRF attack when accessing partially-user-controlled shorthand URLs

extended_information.short_description: A design problem in GNU's Wget may lead to SSRF and various types of attacks by sending crafted data to a server.
extended_information.full_description:
[Wget](https://www.gnu.org/software/wget/) is a popular program that is used to download content from servers and is part of the GNU project. It primarily supports the HTTP and FTP protocols.

In addition to normal URLs (e.g. `http://user@host/file` or `ftp://host/file`), Wget supported shorthand URL formats. For example, `wget userinfo@host/file` would issue a request for `http://userinfo@host/file`, and `wget host:/file` would issue a request for `ftp://host/file`. These two formats have been considered deprecated for quite some time now. They were originally  introduced by NcFTP and Netscape, which is why Wget supported them.

The `userinfo` part of a URL can be used to pass credentials.

It has been discovered that when using the HTTP shorthand format with user-provided input in the `userinfo` part, unexpected behavior may occur. Wget might issue an FTP request to a different host – a potentially attacker-controlled host or a restricted host which the user normally does not have access to. This SSRF vulnerability can be the starting point for many types of attacks.

This vulnerable behavior may occur if user input is provided to the `userinfo` part of a shorthand HTTP request. For example, `wget user_input@reliableserver`. In this example, an input such as `malicious:` would cause Wget to interpret this URL as a shorthanded FTP URL (with the domain `malicious` and the file `@reliableserver`). This will result in Wget issuing an FTP request for the domain `malicious`.

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: The prerequisites for exploiting the issue are extremely unlikely
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description: Exploitation of this vulnerability requires that the application use the HTTP shorthand format with user input in its `userinfo` part. This is very uncommon, so exploitation of this CVE in real-world scenarios is unlikely.

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: The issue can be exploited by attackers over the network
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description: This vulnerability can be exploited remotely by supplying crafted input to a server.

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: The issue has an exploit published
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description: This vulnerability has a published PoC.

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: The impact of exploiting the issue depends on the context of surrounding software. A severe impact such as RCE is not guaranteed.
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description: The impact of this vulnerability depends on how exactly Wget is used in the vulnerable application. Depending on the usage, it may lead to SSRF, MiTM, or data leakage. It may also be helpful in phishing attacks.

extended_information.remediation:
##### Development mitigations

Change all shorthand HTTP requests to their full format. For example, change `wget input@myserver` to `wget http://input@myserver` or preferably to `wget https://input@myserver` if HTTPS is supported.

vulnerabilities.summary: url.c in GNU Wget through 1.24.5 mishandles semicolons in the userinfo subcomponent of a URI, and thus there may be insecure behavior in which data that was supposed to be in the userinfo subcomponent is misinterpreted to be part of the host subcomponent.

extended_information.short_description: A design problem in GNU's Wget may lead to SSRF and various types of attacks, including RCE, by sending crafted data to a server.
extended_information.full_description:
[Wget](https://www.gnu.org/software/wget/) is a popular program that is used to download content from servers and is part of the GNU project. It primarily supports the HTTP and FTP protocols.

[RFC-2396](https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2396) is a standard that defines the syntax and format of a URL. In general, a URL is of the structure `scheme://[userinfo@]host[:port]/path[?query][#fragment]`. The `userinfo` part consists of information about the user, like a username. Although the standard is outdated, it is the standard that is used in Wget’s `url.c` file which is responsible for parsing URLs.

A vulnerability has recently been found in GNU's Wget. It has been discovered that Wget doesn't parse `userinfo` correctly. According to the [standard](https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2396), a URI can include a semicolon in its `userinfo`. However, Wget parses URIs in a way that causes `userinfo` to be considered part of the `host` if it contains a semicolon. This means that both the `userinfo` and the `host` part of the URI could be interpreted incorrectly.

Misinterpretation of the `host` segment might lead to DNS queries being sent to incorrect and potentially malicious domains. By using this vulnerability, attackers can initiate various common attacks - like SSRF, MiTM, and phishing. These attacks can have severe consequences, like resource restriction bypass, sensitive information leakage, and remote code execution.

When Wget is used to connect to an FTP or FTPS URLs the attacker can utilize the CVE to completely replace the hostname that Wget connects to. This is the most severe outcome of exploiting this vulnerability. If the HTTP protocol is used, the attacker can control the hostname but the hostname will contain invalid characters (like a semicolon) that will limit the attack surface and the options to carry out an attack with a severe outcome.

See JFrog's [CVE analysis blog](https://jfrog.com/blog/cve-2024-38428-wget-vuln-all-you-need-to-know/) for proof of concept and more technical details on this vulnerability.

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: The issue has an exploit published
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description: This vulnerability has a published PoC.

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: Exploitation of the issue is only possible when the vulnerable component is used in a specific manner. The attacker has to perform per-target research to determine the vulnerable attack vector
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description: In order to exploit this vulnerability, the attacker must be able to control the `userinfo` segment of a URL that is requested by the server.

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: The issue can be exploited by attackers over the network
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description: This vulnerability can be exploited remotely by supplying crafted input to a server.

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: The impact of exploiting the issue depends on the context of surrounding software. A severe impact such as RCE is not guaranteed.
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description: The impact of this vulnerability is severe if the FTP or the FTPS schemes are used, but negligible if the HTTP or the HTTPS schemes are used. See the vulnerability summary for more details.

extended_information.remediation:
##### Development mitigations

When providing user input to the `userinfo` part of a URL, do not allow a semicolon in this input.

vulnerabilities.summary: GNU Wget through 1.21.1 does not omit the Authorization header upon a redirect to a different origin, a related issue to CVE-2018-1000007.
An issue has been found in libpng 1.6.34. It is a SEGV in the function png_free_data in png.c, related to the recommended error handling for png_read_image.

A heap overflow flaw was found in libpngs' pngimage.c program. This flaw allows an attacker with local network access to pass a specially crafted PNG file to the pngimage utility, causing an application to crash, leading to a denial of service.
png_create_info_struct in png.c in libpng 1.6.36 has a memory leak, as demonstrated by pngcp. NOTE: a third party has stated "I don't think it is libpng's job to free this buffer.

extended_information.short_description: A memory leak in libpng can lead to unspecified impact.
extended_information.full_description:
[libpng](http://www.libpng.org/pub/png/libpng.html) is the official PNG reference library. It supports almost all PNG features, is extensible, and has been extensively tested for over 23 years.

png_create_info_struct in png.c in libpng 1.6.36 has a memory leak, as demonstrated by pngcp.

Even though a memory exhaustion can cause a denial of service in theory, in practice the conditions are highly unlikely and would require a very specific payload.

A [discussion on github](https://github.com/glennrp/libpng/issues/269) suggests that "the memory is leaked during abort(), so in the vast majority of cases there's no leak at all".

Also in the same discussion, it is suggested that the leaked buffer should be freed by pngcp (the code using the library), not libpng itself.

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: The issue has been disputed by the vendor
The prerequisites for exploiting the issue are extremely unlikely
The issue cannot result in a severe impact (such as remote code execution)
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description: Possible DoS

vulnerabilities.summary: An issue has been found in third-party PNM decoding associated with libpng 1.6.35. It is a stack-based buffer overflow in the function get_token in pnm2png.c in pnm2png.

contrib/slapd-modules/nops/nops.c in OpenLDAP through 2.4.45, when both the nops module and the memberof overlay are enabled, attempts to free a buffer that was allocated on the stack, which allows remote attackers to cause a denial of service (slapd crash) via a member MODDN operation.

libldap in certain third-party OpenLDAP packages has a certificate-validation flaw when the third-party package is asserting RFC6125 support. It considers CN even when there is a non-matching subjectAltName (SAN). This is fixed in, for example, openldap-2.4.46-10.el8 in Red Hat Enterprise Linux.

slapd in OpenLDAP 2.4.45 and earlier creates a PID file after dropping privileges to a non-root account, which might allow local users to kill arbitrary processes by leveraging access to this non-root account for PID file modification before a root script executes a "kill `cat /pathname`" command, as demonstrated by openldap-initscript.

The nss_parse_ciphers function in libraries/libldap/tls_m.c in OpenLDAP does not properly parse OpenSSL-style multi-keyword mode cipher strings, which might cause a weaker than intended cipher to be used and allow remote attackers to have unspecified impact via unknown vectors.
A vulnerability was found in openldap. This security flaw causes a null pointer dereference in ber_memalloc_x() function.

A vulnerability was found in Mercurial SCM 4.5.3/71.19.145.211. It has been declared as problematic. This vulnerability affects unknown code of the component Web Interface. The manipulation of the argument cmd leads to cross site scripting. The attack can be initiated remotely. The exploit has been disclosed to the public and may be used. The vendor was contacted early about this disclosure but did not respond in any way.
SQLite3 from 3.6.0 to and including 3.27.2 is vulnerable to heap out-of-bound read in the rtreenode() function when handling invalid rtree tables.

extended_information.short_description: SQLite3 is vulnerable to heap out-of-bounds read in the rtreenode() function when accessing malicious SQLite databases.
extended_information.full_description:
[SQLite](https://www.sqlite.org/index.html) is a very popular lightweight SQL database engine. An [R-Tree](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/R-tree) is a special index that is designed for doing range queries. R-Trees are most commonly used in geospatial systems where each entry is a rectangle with minimum and maximum X and Y coordinates. Given a query rectangle, an R-Tree is able to quickly find all entries that are contained within the query rectangle or which overlap the query rectangle.

Even though no exploit is published, it's possible in theory to cause a heap out-of-bounds read using a crafted rtree table, leading to potential disclosure of information. The attacker would have to cause the victim to open a specially-crafted SQLite DB. In addition - the attacker would need to be familiar with the queries executed by the vicitm.

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: The prerequisites for exploiting the issue are extremely unlikely
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description: The attacker would have to cause the victim to open a specially-crafted SQLite DB. In addition - the attacker would need to be familiar with the queries executed by the vicitm (to generate a relevant malicious SQLite DB)

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: No high-impact exploit or technical writeup were published, and exploitation of the issue with high impact is either non-trivial or completely unproven
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description: This is memory corruption vulnerability which requires a high level of sophistication to exploit.

vulnerabilities.summary: A vulnerability was found in OpenSSH when the VerifyHostKeyDNS option is enabled. A machine-in-the-middle attack can be performed by a malicious machine impersonating a legit server. This issue occurs due to how OpenSSH mishandles error codes in specific conditions when verifying the host key. For an attack to be considered successful, the attacker needs to manage to exhaust the client's memory resource first, turning the attack complexity high.

extended_information.short_description: A design problem in OpenSSH may allow network attackers to perform man-in-the-middle attacks when VerifyHostKeyDNS is enabled.
extended_information.full_description:
[OpenSSH](https://www.openssh.com/) is a popular open-source implementation of the SSH (Secure Shell) protocol, providing encrypted communication over a network.
`VerifyHostKeyDNS` feature in OpenSSH enables the SSH client to authenticate a server's host key by querying DNS for its SSHFP (SSH Fingerprint) record. When active, this feature checks the server's fingerprint in DNS to confirm its legitimacy before making a connection.
CVE-2025-26465 relies on the `VerifyHostKeyDNS` feature, which is not enabled by default (in FreeBSD the feature was enabled by default from 2013 to 2023).

Exploiting CVE-2025-26465 in a MiTM attack could potentially cause the SSH client to accept an attacker’s key instead of the legitimate server's, compromising the connection’s integrity. This would allow attackers to intercept or manipulate the session, potentially stealing credentials or accessing sensitive information. This attack will require the `VerifyHostKeyDNS` to be set in the client.

Currently successful exploitation of this CVE requires another vulnerability (such as CVE-2025-26466) in order to cause an out-of-memory error in the client. This will enable the attacker to later on use CVE-2025-26465 to bypass authentication.

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: The issue has a detailed technical explanation published, that can aid in exploit development
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description: Qualys research team has published a technical write-up on the issue.

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: The issue results in a severe impact (such as remote code execution)
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description: Data leakage.

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: The issue can be exploited by attackers over the network
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description: The attacker must be able to intercept the communication between the application and the server using a man-in-the-middle attack.

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: No high-impact exploit or technical writeup were published, and exploitation of the issue with high impact is either non-trivial or completely unproven
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description:
Currently, no public exploit has been published that will allow a man-in-the-middle attack on OpenSSH clients by using CVE-2025-26465 alone. The suggested attack scenario so far requires exhausting the client's memory by sending the client a large key (which is limited to 256kb) and finding a memory leak in the client’s code. These 2 conditions make this attack highly unlikely.
Note: another vulnerability (such as CVE-2025-26466) may be used to successfully exploit CVE-2025-26465.

vulnerabilities.summary: The client side in OpenSSH 5.7 through 8.4 has an Observable Discrepancy leading to an information leak in the algorithm negotiation. This allows man-in-the-middle attackers to target initial connection attempts (where no host key for the server has been cached by the client). NOTE: some reports state that 8.5 and 8.6 are also affected.

An issue was discovered in OpenSSH before 8.9. If a client is using public-key authentication with agent forwarding but without -oLogLevel=verbose, and an attacker has silently modified the server to support the None authentication option, then the user cannot determine whether FIDO authentication is going to confirm that the user wishes to connect to that server, or that the user wishes to allow that server to connect to a different server on the user's behalf. NOTE: the vendor's position is "this is not an authentication bypass, since nothing is being bypassed.

Remotely observable behaviour in auth-gss2.c in OpenSSH through 7.8 could be used by remote attackers to detect existence of users on a target system when GSS2 is in use. NOTE: the discoverer states 'We understand that the OpenSSH developers do not want to treat such a username enumeration (or "oracle") as a vulnerability.'

A signal handler race condition was found in OpenSSH's server (sshd), where a client does not authenticate within LoginGraceTime seconds (120 by default, 600 in old OpenSSH versions), then sshd's SIGALRM handler is called asynchronously. However, this signal handler calls various functions that are not async-signal-safe, for example, syslog().

sshd in OpenSSH 6.2 through 8.x before 8.8, when certain non-default configurations are used, allows privilege escalation because supplemental groups are not initialized as expected. Helper programs for AuthorizedKeysCommand and AuthorizedPrincipalsCommand may run with privileges associated with group memberships of the sshd process, if the configuration specifies running the command as a different user.

OpenSSH through 9.6, when common types of DRAM are used, might allow row hammer attacks (for authentication bypass) because the integer value of authenticated in mm_answer_authpassword does not resist flips of a single bit. NOTE: this is applicable to a certain threat model of attacker-victim co-location in which the attacker has user privileges.

extended_information.short_description: The RowHammer fault injection attack can theoretically lead to local authentication bypass in OpenSSH.
extended_information.full_description:
[OpenSSH](https://www.openssh.com/) is a popular open-source implementation of the SSH (Secure Shell) protocol, providing encrypted communication over a network.
It was discovered that the OpenSSH authentication logic can be susceptible in some cases to a side-channel fault injection attack. The attack can theoretically be carried out by a local attacker which eventually bypass OpenSSH authentication mechanism.

This vulnerability currently lacks widely known published exploits, and its exploitation is considered highly complex. The intricacies of the attack, combined with the absence of well-documented exploits, contribute to the difficulty in achieving successful exploitation. Furthermore, it's essential to note that the susceptibility to this vulnerability is hardware-dependent, and the success of an attack relies on probabilities associated with the specific hardware configuration. 

The vulnerability is theoretically exploitable by several different ways, the only two published ways are:

In the OpenSSH function `mm_answer_authpassword()`, a stack variable `authenticated`, is assigned to the value of the function `auth_password()` which returns 1/0 and then returned. If the value of `authenticated` is 1, the SSH connection will be established. Since `authenticated` is stored on the stack, therefore in DRAM, a local attacker could flip this 32-bit integer least significant bit, thus, bypass authentication.

Another possible exploit is the `result` stack variable in `auth_password()` function. It is initialized to 0 and set to 1 if the password is correct. 
Similarly to the previous method, this attack requires a single bit flip of the `result` variable in order for the function to return 1 and bypass the authentication.

Attackers can trigger the vulnerability via a RowHammer fault injection. The Rowhammer bug is a hardware reliability issue in which an attacker repeatedly accesses (hammers) DRAM cells to cause unauthorized changes in physically adjacent memory locations.
Simply put:

* A specific register value(`authenticated`/`result` value) is pushed onto the stack during program execution. 
* The stack, where the register value is stored, is identified to be located in a memory row susceptible to bit flips (flippable row) due to the RowHammer vulnerability in DRAM.
* The attacker performs a series of rapid and repeated memory accesses to the adjacent rows of the flippable row in the DRAM. This repeated access exploits the RowHammer vulnerability, inducing bit flips in the targeted flippable row.
* Due to the RowHammer effect, bit flips occur in the flippable row, potentially corrupting the data stored there.
* After inducing bit flips in the flippable row, the attacker manipulates the program's control flow to pop the corrupted value from the stack into a register.
* The register now holds a value that has been corrupted through the RowHammer attack. Now the `authenticated`/`result` variables hold this corrupted value thus it can lead to authentication bypass, as it may impact the control flow in a way advantageous to the attacker.

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: Exploitation of the issue is only possible when the vulnerable component is used in a specific manner. The attacker has to perform per-target research to determine the vulnerable attack vector
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description: The vulnerability depends on the OS and hardware. It was only evaluated in one test environment, therefore results for other conditions might differ. The attacker must be extremely familiar with the details of the exploited system (ex. know the exact hardware which is running the OS).

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: The issue can only be exploited by an attacker that can execute code on the vulnerable machine (excluding exceedingly rare circumstances)
No high-impact exploit or technical writeup were published, and exploitation of the issue with high impact is either non-trivial or completely unproven
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description: Exploitation is extremely non-trivial (even theoretically), no public exploits have been published.

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: The reported CVSS was either wrongly calculated, downgraded by other vendors, or does not reflect the vulnerability's impact
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description: The vulnerability's attack complexity is significantly higher than what the CVSS represents.

vulnerabilities.summary: OpenSSH 7.7 through 7.9 and 8.x before 8.1, when compiled with an experimental key type, has a pre-authentication integer overflow if a client or server is configured to use a crafted XMSS key. This leads to memory corruption and local code execution because of an error in the XMSS key parsing algorithm. NOTE: the XMSS implementation is considered experimental in all released OpenSSH versions, and there is no supported way to enable it when building portable OpenSSH.

extended_information.short_description: An integer overflow in OpenSSH can lead to remote code execution when parsing crafted XMSS private keys.
extended_information.full_description:
An integer overflow was discovered in OpenSSH, when parsing XMSS private keys, which leads to a heap-based buffer overflow. A [crashing PoC](https://0day.life/exploits/0day-1009.html) has been publicly demonstrated, but not RCE exploit has been publicly shown nor discussed (and was mentioned in the technical writeup as a "non-trivial task")

To exploit this issue, OpenSSH must be compiled with the (nondefault) `WITH_XMSS` compilation macro, (which cannot be enabled through normal OpenSSH compilation on Linux) and configured to accept XMSS private keys in one of the following ways:

1. A hosting service which allow users to upload their own public/private keypair (this is the most likely scenario)

2. Adding a crafted XMSS key to ssh-agent

3. If 'authorized_keys' is configured to use an XMSS public key, and an XMSS private key is used to connect to the server, the ssh client used for the connection will crash.

4. If ‘sshd’ daemon is configured to use an XMSS host key that is malformed, it will crash upon any attempt to connect to this server (extremely unlikely)

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: The issue can only be exploited by an attacker that can execute code on the vulnerable machine (excluding exceedingly rare circumstances)
The prerequisites for exploiting the issue are extremely unlikely
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description: OpenSSH compiled with XMSS support that accepts XMSS private keys on runtime

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: No high-impact exploit or technical writeup were published, and exploitation of the issue with high impact is either non-trivial or completely unproven

vulnerabilities.summary: scp in OpenSSH through 8.3p1 allows command injection in the scp.c toremote function, as demonstrated by backtick characters in the destination argument. NOTE: the vendor reportedly has stated that they intentionally omit validation of "anomalous argument transfers" because that could "stand a great chance of breaking existing workflows."

The scp client in OpenSSH 8.2 incorrectly sends duplicate responses to the server upon a utimes system call failure, which allows a malicious unprivileged user on the remote server to overwrite arbitrary files in the client's download directory by creating a crafted subdirectory anywhere on the remote server. The victim must use the command scp -rp to download a file hierarchy containing, anywhere inside, this crafted subdirectory. NOTE: the vendor points out that "this attack can achieve no more than a hostile peer is already able to achieve within the scp protocol" and "utimes does not fail under normal circumstances.
In sshd in OpenSSH before 10.0, the DisableForwarding directive does not adhere to the documentation stating that it disables X11 and agent forwarding.

A flaw was found in the OpenSSH package. For each ping packet the SSH server receives, a pong packet is allocated in a memory buffer and stored in a queue of packages. It is only freed when the server/client key exchange has finished. A malicious client may keep sending such packages, leading to an uncontrolled increase in memory consumption on the server side. Consequently, the server may become unavailable, resulting in a denial of service attack.

OpenSSH, when using OPIE (One-Time Passwords in Everything) for PAM, allows remote attackers to determine the existence of certain user accounts, which displays a different response if the user account exists and is configured to use one-time passwords (OTP), a similar issue to CVE-2007-2243.

extended_information.short_description: OpenSSH allows remote attackers to determine the existence of certain user accounts when using OPIE (One-Time Passwords in Everything) for PAM.
extended_information.full_description:
OpenSSH is a famous connectivity tool for remote login with the SSH protocol.

When the `ChallengeResponseAuthentication` option is enabled in OpenSSH configuration file located at `/etc/ssh/sshd_config`, it allows remote attackers to determine **the existence of user accounts** by attempting to authenticate via `S/KEY`, which displays a different response if the user account exists.

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: The prerequisites for exploiting the issue are extremely unlikely
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description: OpenSSH configurations enabling S/KEY and OTP are extremely rare

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: The issue cannot result in a severe impact (such as remote code execution)
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description: Marked as unimportant by the Debian tracker, data leak is minimal (asserting if a specific user exists or not)

vulnerabilities.summary: OpenSSH through 8.7 allows remote attackers, who have a suspicion that a certain combination of username and public key is known to an SSH server, to test whether this suspicion is correct. This occurs because a challenge is sent only when that combination could be valid for a login session. NOTE: the vendor does not recognize user enumeration as a vulnerability for this product

In ssh in OpenSSH before 9.6, OS command injection might occur if a user name or host name has shell metacharacters, and this name is referenced by an expansion token in certain situations. For example, an untrusted Git repository can have a submodule with shell metacharacters in a user name or host name.

extended_information.short_description: Missing input validations in OpenSSH can lead to command injection when connecting to a host with a specific ProxyCommand configuration.
extended_information.full_description:
[OpenSSH](https://www.openssh.com/) is a popular open-source implementation of the SSH (Secure Shell) protocol, providing encrypted communication over a network.
OpenSSH configuration is a text file that allows users to customize the behavior of the OpenSSH client and server. The configuration file is usually located at `/etc/ssh/sshd_config` for the server and `~/.ssh/config` for the client.

Its goal is to specify various settings, such as host-specific options, preferred algorithms, and authentication methods. When a `Host` is defined, the configuration allows users to set parameters specifically for connections to that host. The non-default `ProxyCommand` directive, when used, specifies the command to use for connecting to the server via a proxy, enabling users to traverse intermediate hosts or jump hosts to reach their destination.

Example of configuration using ProxyCommand:
```
Host *.example.com
 ProxyCommand /usr/bin/nc -X connect -x 192.0.2.0:8080 %h %p 
```
In this example, at each SSH connection to `example.com`, the `ProxyCommand` command will be executed and the tokens will be expanded accordingly. Especially, `%h` and `%r` are tokens for the hostname and the remote username.
Both tokens are expanded and the value is directly copied instead of being checked before. Thus, if the attackers control the hostname/remote username, they can theoretically inject commands in the ProxyCommand command. 
Thus, this example of configuration is vulnerable as it uses `ProxyCommand` with the `%h` token.

To exploit this issue, the attacker has to control the OpenSSH configuration (which is very unlikely to be controlled by users) or to be able to exploit a non-default existing `ProxyCommand` configuration and cause the client to perform requests to a malicious hostname in the domain range of the pre-configured `Host` directive (like *.example.com as demonstrated above)

[An interesting PoC that was published](https://github.com/vin01/poc-proxycommand-vulnerable) for this CVE demonstrates how a pre-configured `ProxyCommand` can be exploited. The public PoC triggers the issue through a remote Git submodule. The attacker hides the malicious shell command in a .gitmodules file and when the victim recursively clones the malicious repository, git uses SSH to clone the malicious submodule. Since git uses SSH with the configuration's Host, OpenSSH will replace %h with the attacker-controlled hostname containing the malicious cmd and execute the `ProxyCommand`. The use of shell metacharacters allows the attacker to use command substitution (`) and run arbitrary code.

The exploitation requirement of a non-default OpenSSH config minimizes the number of vulnerable machines and limits the issue for specific scenarios like cloning a malicious Git repo. It is still possible other attack scenarios are exploitable, so this issue is worth mitigating.

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description: This issue can lead to RCE.

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: The issue has an exploit published
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description: The PoC available gives a real scenario in which case this issue can be used.

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: Exploiting the issue requires the user to interact with the vulnerable software
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description: As demonstrated in the PoC, the victim host's user should trigger the issue by cloning a vulnerable git repository.

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: The prerequisites for exploiting the issue are extremely unlikely
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description: To exploit this issue, the attacker has to control the OpenSSH configuration (which is very unlikely to be controlled by users) or to be able to exploit a non-default existing `ProxyCommand` configuration and cause the client to perform requests to a malicious hostname in the domain range of the pre-configured `Host` directive (like *.example.com as demonstrated above).

extended_information.remediation:
##### Deployment mitigations

Avoid having SSH configuration for a wide range of hostnames and specify hostnames explicitly (Avoid using `*` in the `Host` directive). Thus, the token `%h` is not required and can be directly replaced by the hostname itself.

vulnerabilities.summary: In OpenSSH 7.9, due to accepting and displaying arbitrary stderr output from the server, a malicious server (or Man-in-The-Middle attacker) can manipulate the client output, for example to use ANSI control codes to hide additional files being transferred.

OpenSSH 4.6 and earlier, when ChallengeResponseAuthentication is enabled, allows remote attackers to determine the existence of user accounts by attempting to authenticate via S/KEY, which displays a different response if the user account exists, a similar issue to CVE-2001-1483.

The SSH transport protocol with certain OpenSSH extensions, found in OpenSSH before 9.6 and other products, allows remote attackers to bypass integrity checks such that some packets are omitted (from the extension negotiation message), and a client and server may consequently end up with a connection for which some security features have been downgraded or disabled, aka a Terrapin attack. This occurs because the SSH Binary Packet Protocol (BPP), implemented by these extensions, mishandles the handshake phase and mishandles use of sequence numbers. For example, there is an effective attack against SSH's use of ChaCha20-Poly1305 (and CBC with Encrypt-then-MAC). The bypass occurs in chacha20-poly1305@openssh.com and (if CBC is used) the -etm@openssh.com MAC algorithms. This also affects Maverick Synergy Java SSH API before 3.1.0-SNAPSHOT, Dropbear through 2022.83, Ssh before 5.1.1 in Erlang/OTP, PuTTY before 0.80, AsyncSSH before 2.14.2, golang.org/x/crypto before 0.17.0, libssh before 0.10.6, libssh2 through 1.11.0, Thorn Tech SFTP Gateway before 3.4.6, Tera Term before 5.1, Paramiko before 3.4.0, jsch before 0.2.15, SFTPGo before 2.5.6, Netgate pfSense Plus through 23.09.1, Netgate pfSense CE through 2.7.2, HPN-SSH through 18.2.0, ProFTPD before 1.3.8b (and before 1.3.9rc2), ORYX CycloneSSH before 2.3.4, NetSarang XShell 7 before Build 0144, CrushFTP before 10.6.0, ConnectBot SSH library before 2.2.22, Apache MINA sshd through 2.11.0, sshj through 0.37.0, TinySSH through 20230101, trilead-ssh2 6401, LANCOM LCOS and LANconfig, FileZilla before 3.66.4, Nova before 11.8, PKIX-SSH before 14.4, SecureCRT before 9.4.3, Transmit5 before 5.10.4, Win32-OpenSSH before 9.5.0.0p1-Beta, WinSCP before 6.2.2, Bitvise SSH Server before 9.32, Bitvise SSH Client before 9.33, KiTTY through 0.76.1.13, the net-ssh gem 7.2.0 for Ruby, the mscdex ssh2 module before 1.15.0 for Node.js, the thrussh library before 0.35.1 for Rust, and the Russh crate before 0.40.2 for Rust.

extended_information.short_description: A design problem in the SSH protocol may lead to a connection security downgrade by local network attackers via MitM.
extended_information.full_description:
SSH (Secure Shell) is a cryptographic network protocol that provides a secure way to access and manage remote systems over an unsecured network. [OpenSSH](https://www.openssh.com/) refers to an open-source implementation of the SSH (Secure Shell) protocol, offering encrypted communication for secure access to remote systems over networks.

[AES](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Advanced_Encryption_Standard) (Advanced Encryption Standard) is a widely-used symmetric encryption algorithm that ensures secure and efficient encryption and decryption of data.

The Terrapin attack is a novel cryptographic attack in the SSH protocol itself, causing the compromised client to erroneously perceive that the server lacks support for recent signature algorithms used in user authentication, through a man-in-the-middle (MitM) attack. It affects a wide range of implementations, including but not limited to OpenSSH, Paramiko, and others. 

There are two vulnerable SSH configurations:
1. `ChaCha20-Poly1305`
2. Any `aes(128|192|256)-cbc` ciphers using the default MACs (or any MAC that uses Encrypt-then-MAC, EtM, for example - `hmac-sha2-256-etm@openssh.com`).

The default OpenSSH client and server are vulnerable to this attack, as they are configured to allow the vulnerable `ChaCha20-Poly1305` cipher. 

Note that updating either the server or client is not enough! Both must be patched. A vulnerable client connecting to a fixed server will still result in a vulnerable connection.

In OpenSSH 9.5, a new feature involving [keystroke timing obfuscation](https://lwn.net/Articles/298833/) was introduced. This attack enables a MitM attacker to disable this feature, and consequently to perform a keystroke timing attack against OpenSSH.

The researchers describe the ChaCha20-Poly1305 cipher integration as easier to exploit than the aes-cbc EtM. 

In this scenario, a prefix truncation attack is employed, wherein the attacker manipulates sequence numbers to selectively delete chosen packets from the start of a communication channel, compromising channel integrity without detection. Specifically, the attacker can omit the `EXT_INFO` message, crucial for negotiating various protocol extensions (specific signature algorithms) without detection by the client or server. To evade detection, the attacker introduces an ignored packet during the handshake, ensuring the sequence numbers remain aligned.

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: The issue has multiple mentions in general media
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description: The vulnerability is an inherent flaw in the SSH protocol itself, which affects a wide range of implementations, including but not limited to OpenSSH, Paramiko, and others. Also, the vulnerability received a lot of media attention.

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: The issue has a detailed technical explanation published, that can aid in exploit development
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description: The researchers who found this vulnerability published an academic paper regarding it.

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: Exploitation of the issue is only possible when the vulnerable component is used in a specific manner. The attacker has to perform per-target research to determine the vulnerable attack vector
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description:
The attacker must be able to perform a man-in-the-middle attack on an SSH client or server.
Additionally, the SSH server must use a specific configuration:
1. Enable the `ChaCha20-Poly1305` cipher (enabled by default)
OR
2. Enable any `aes(128|192|256)-cbc` ciphers using the default MACs (or any MAC that uses Encrypt-then-MAC, EtM, for example - `hmac-sha2-256-etm@openssh.com`).

The default OpenSSH client and server are vulnerable to this attack, as they are configured to allow the vulnerable `ChaCha20-Poly1305` cipher. 

Moreover, both SSH server and client must be patched to avoid vulnerable connections.

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: No high-impact exploit or technical writeup were published, and exploitation of the issue with high impact is either non-trivial or completely unproven
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description:
Although an academic paper was published, no specific implementation of an exploit was shared.
It requires a deep understanding of the SSH protocol and substantial further research.

extended_information.remediation:
##### Deployment mitigations

To mitigate this, one can disable the vulnerable `ChaCha20-Poly1305` cipher in the OpenSSH server configuration.
Specifically, add the following to your `/etc/ssh/ssh(d)_config`: `Ciphers -chacha20-poly1305@openssh.com`.
Note the `-` at the start of the chacha20 cipher string.
Then, restart your SSH server for it to take effect.

In addition, ensure you’re not explicitly enabling any `aes(128|192|256)-cbc` ciphers in your OpenSSH configuration while using the default MACs (these ciphers are disabled by default)

vulnerabilities.summary: OpenSSH 9.5 through 9.7 before 9.8 sometimes allows timing attacks against echo-off password entry (e.g., for su and Sudo) because of an ObscureKeystrokeTiming logic error. Similarly, other timing attacks against keystroke entry could occur.

sshd in OpenSSH 4 on Debian GNU/Linux, and the 20070303 OpenSSH snapshot, allows remote authenticated users to obtain access to arbitrary SELinux roles by appending a :/ (colon slash) sequence, followed by the role name, to the username.
libheif before 1.19.6 has a NULL pointer dereference in ImageItem_Grid::get_decoder in image-items/grid.cc because a grid image can reference a nonexistent image item.
libheif before 1.19.6 has a NULL pointer dereference in ImageItem_iden in image-items/iden.cc.
In Libheif 1.17.6, insufficient checks in ImageOverlay::parse() decoding a heif file containing an overlay image with forged offsets can lead to an out-of-bounds read and write.

extended_information.short_description: An integer overflow in libheif leads to denial of service and possibly remote code execution when parsing crafted images.

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description: Remote code execution.

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description: An attacker would need to find input propagating into the libheif decoding function `heif_decode_image`.

vulnerabilities.summary: There is a vulnerability in the strided image data parsing code in the emscripten wrapper for libheif. An attacker could exploit this through a crafted image file to cause a buffer overflow in linear memory during a memcpy call.
Floating point exception in function Fraction in libheif 1.4.0, allows attackers to cause a Denial of Service or possibly other unspecified impacts.

Buffer overflow vulnerability in function convert_colorspace in heif_colorconversion.cc in libheif v1.6.2, allows attackers to cause a denial of service and disclose sensitive information, via a crafted HEIF file.
libheif <= 1.17.6 contains a memory leak in the function JpegEncoder::Encode. This flaw allows an attacker to cause a denial of service attack.
A Segmentation fault caused by a floating point exception exists in libheif 1.15.1 using crafted heif images via the heif::Fraction::round() function in box.cc, which causes a denial of service.
An issue was discovered in heif::Box_iref::get_references in libheif 1.4.0, allows attackers to cause a Denial of Service or possibly other unspecified impact due to an invalid memory read.

It was discovered that there was a ECDSA timing attack in the libgcrypt20 cryptographic library. Version affected: 1.8.4-5, 1.7.6-2+deb9u3, and 1.6.3-2+deb8u4. Versions fixed: 1.8.5-2 and 1.6.3-2+deb8u7.

A timing-based side-channel flaw was found in libgcrypt's RSA implementation. This issue may allow a remote attacker to initiate a Bleichenbacher-style attack, which can lead to the decryption of RSA ciphertexts.

Libgcrypt before 1.8.8 and 1.9.x before 1.9.3 mishandles ElGamal encryption because it lacks exponent blinding to address a side-channel attack against mpi_powm, and the window size is not chosen appropriately. This, for example, affects use of ElGamal in OpenPGP.

extended_information.short_description: Timing data leak in libgcrypt ElGamal encryption can lead to key brute force when attackers can cause many decryption operations.
extended_information.full_description:
[Libgcrypt](https://gnupg.org/software/libgcrypt/index.html) is a general-purpose cryptographic library based on the code from GnuPG.
[ElGamal encryption](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ElGamal_encryption) is a public-key cryptosystem that is widely used in OpenPGP for key management and encrypted communication.

In ElGamal encryption, the encryption operation involves raising a message to the power of the public key. An attacker might be able to perform a timing attack to extract information about the private key by observing the time it takes to perform the encryption.

To perform this attack, an attacker would need to be on the same machine or subnet where the decryption takes place, and be able to trigger many decryption operations (oracle attack).

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description: The attacker would need to be able to trigger many decryption operations (oracle attack).

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: The prerequisites for exploiting the issue are extremely unlikely
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description: ElGamal is rarely used alone (used more as part of a hybrid encryption type)

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: The issue can only be exploited by an attacker that can execute code on the vulnerable machine (excluding exceedingly rare circumstances)
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description: Due to the nature of timing attacks, the attack would be much more successful by an attacker that can already run code on the machine that performs the decryption. At most, the attacker needs to be on the same subnet as the decryption machine.

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description: The paper gives all the details to exploit this issue.

vulnerabilities.summary: cipher/elgamal.c in Libgcrypt through 1.8.2, when used to encrypt messages directly, improperly encodes plaintexts, which allows attackers to obtain sensitive information by reading ciphertext data (i.e., it does not have semantic security in face of a ciphertext-only attack). The Decisional Diffie-Hellman (DDH) assumption does not hold for Libgcrypt's ElGamal implementation.
libexpat through 2.6.1 allows an XML Entity Expansion attack when there is isolated use of external parsers (created via XML_ExternalEntityParserCreate).

expat 2.1.0 and earlier does not properly handle entities expansion unless an application developer uses the XML_SetEntityDeclHandler function, which allows remote attackers to cause a denial of service (resource consumption), send HTTP requests to intranet servers, or read arbitrary files via a crafted XML document, aka an XML External Entity (XXE) issue.  NOTE: it could be argued that because expat already provides the ability to disable external entity expansion, the responsibility for resolving this issue lies with application developers; according to this argument, this entry should be REJECTed, and each affected application would need its own CVE.
libexpat through 2.5.0 allows recursive XML Entity Expansion if XML_DTD is undefined at compile time.
An issue was discovered in libexpat before 2.6.3. dtdCopy in xmlparse.c can have an integer overflow for nDefaultAtts on 32-bit platforms (where UINT_MAX equals SIZE_MAX).

extended_information.short_description: An integer overflow in libexpat may lead to remote code execution when parsing a crafted XML document.

vulnerabilities.summary: An issue was discovered in libexpat before 2.6.3. xmlparse.c does not reject a negative length for XML_ParseBuffer.

extended_information.short_description: Heap buffer overflow in Expat leads to possible remote code execution when accepting negative buffer sizes in XML_ParseBuffer
extended_information.full_description:
[Expat](https://libexpat.github.io/) is a stream-oriented XML parser written in C.

It has been discovered that `XML_ParseBuffer()` in Expat before 2.6.3 doesn't validate whether its `len` argument is positive. This argument specifies the length of the XML document that should be parsed by the function. By passing a negative length to `XML_ParseBuffer()`, an attacker can cause incorrect parsing of the XML document, which might lead to memory corruption. Although currently unproven, this might lead to remote code execution.

In order to exploit this vulnerability, an attacker must be able to control the `len` parameter which is passed to `XML_ParseBuffer()`. This is highly unlikely, since the developer would usually supply the length of the XML document by themselves (for example by using `stat` or `XML_GetBuffer` ).

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: The issue results in a severe impact (such as remote code execution)
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description: The impact of this vulnerability is denial of service and potentially more severe outcomes such as RCE.

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: The prerequisites for exploiting the issue are extremely unlikely
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description: The attacker must be able to control the `len` which is passed to `XML_ParseBuffer`. This is highly unlikely, since most commonly the developer would check the length of the XML document by themselves, or pass the `len` returned to them by `XML_GetBuffer`.

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: No high-impact exploit or technical writeup were published, and exploitation of the issue with high impact is either non-trivial or completely unproven

extended_information.remediation:
##### Development mitigations

This vulnerability can be mitigated by validating that the `len` which is passed to `XML_ParseBuffer()` is not negative.
