vulnerabilities.summary: An issue was discovered in libexpat before 2.6.4. There is a crash within the XML_ResumeParser function because XML_StopParser can stop/suspend an unstarted parser.

A stack overflow vulnerability exists in the libexpat library due to the way it handles recursive entity expansion in XML documents. When parsing an XML document with deeply nested entity references, libexpat can be forced to recurse indefinitely, exhausting the stack space and causing a crash. This issue could lead to denial of service (DoS) or, in some cases, exploitable memory corruption, depending on the environment and library usage.

extended_information.short_description: A design problem in libexpat may lead to denial of service when parsing a crafted XML document.
extended_information.full_description:
[Expat](https://libexpat.github.io/) is a stream-oriented XML parser written in C.

When parsing an XML document, it is required to map tags into entities that represent data items and can be used throughout the document. 

It has been discovered that entity resolution and substitution were implemented via the recursive function `processInternalEntity()` without adequate depth limitations for all relevant cases. This may lead to the exhaustion of the stack, resulting in a denial of service. 

To exploit this vulnerability, an attacker must be able to parse their crafted XML using `XML_ParseBuffer()` or `XML_Parse()`.

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: Exploitation of the issue is only possible when the vulnerable component is used in a specific manner. The attacker has to perform per-target research to determine the vulnerable attack vector
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description: A potential attacker must be able to feed custom XML files to `XML_ParseBuffer()` or `XML_Parse()`.

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: The issue has a detailed technical explanation published, that can aid in exploit development
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description: A PoC was published demonstrating denial of service including a write-up.

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: The issue results in a severe impact (such as remote code execution)
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description: May lead to denial-of-service.

vulnerabilities.summary: A stack buffer overflow was found in Internationl components for unicode (ICU ). While running the genrb binary, the 'subtag' struct overflowed at the SRBRoot::addTag function. This issue may lead to memory corruption and local arbitrary code execution.

extended_information.short_description: A stack buffer overflow in the genrb tool may lead to remote code execution when parsing crafted input.
extended_information.full_description:
[The Unicode ICU (International Components for Unicode)](https://icu.unicode.org/) library is a widely used open-source software library that provides robust and full-featured Unicode and globalization support for software applications. It offers tools and APIs for handling text in multiple languages.

The `genrb` binary is a tool that comes with the ICU (International Components for Unicode) library. Its main purpose is to compile .txt resource bundle files into binary .res files. These resource bundles contain locale-specific data (like translations, date formats, etc.) used by ICU for internationalization.

A buffer overflow vulnerability was found in `genrb` which may lead to remote code execution when a crafted txt file is provided into the `genrb` CLI. Specifically the `SRBRoot::addTag` must be used in order to exploit this vulnerability. 

NOTE: This vulnerability is limited only to the use of the `genrb` binary and not to the use of the ICU library.

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: The issue has an exploit published
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description: An exploit demonstrating denial of service has been published.

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: The prerequisites for exploiting the issue are extremely unlikely
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description: To successfully exploit this CVE, an attacker must convince the user to use a crafted txt file or be able to run the genrb tool locally, which is very unlikely.

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: Exploiting the issue requires the user to interact with the vulnerable software
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description: The victim must open the attacker's crafted text file in `genrb`.

vulnerabilities.summary: XZ Utils provide a general-purpose data-compression library plus command-line tools. In XZ Utils 5.3.3alpha to 5.8.0, the multithreaded .xz decoder in liblzma has a bug where invalid input can at least result in a crash. The effects include heap use after free and writing to an address based on the null pointer plus an offset. Applications and libraries that use the lzma_stream_decoder_mt function are affected. The bug has been fixed in XZ Utils 5.8.1, and the fix has been committed to the v5.4, v5.6, v5.8, and master branches in the xz Git repository. No new release packages will be made from the old stable branches, but a standalone patch is available that applies to all affected releases.

extended_information.short_description: A use-after-free in XZ-Utils may lead to denial of service when using multithreaded decompression.
extended_information.full_description:
[XZ-Utils](https://github.com/tukaani-project/xz) provides a general-purpose data-compression library plus command-line tools. 

The XZ-Utils CLI tool allows users to choose to decompress an archive using a multithreaded process by utilizing the `--threads` or `-T` flags, followed by the number of threads to be used. When these flags are set to a number other than `1`, the multithreaded decompression algorithm is used.

A flaw in memory management may result in use-after-free because a thread frees the input buffer when `worker_decoder()` is called while another thread writes to it, resulting in a denial-of-service. The vulnerability is mitigated by using single-threaded decompression.

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: Exploitation of the issue is only possible when the vulnerable component is used in a specific manner. The attacker has to perform per-target research to determine the vulnerable attack vector
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description: For the vulnerability to be exploitable, a potential attacker should have the ability to have their maliciously crafted archive decompressed by the user in a multithreaded decompression.

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: The prerequisites for exploiting the issue are extremely unlikely
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description: Since XZ-Utils typically does not use multithreaded decompression, it's unlikely that a maliciously crafted archive would be processed in the specific vulnerable way it requires.

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: No high-impact exploit or technical writeup were published, and exploitation of the issue with high impact is either non-trivial or completely unproven
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description: There is no technical write-up or proof-of-concept for the vulnerability, and exploitation of the issue would require having deep internal knowledge of the library.

vulnerabilities.summary: libjpeg 9c has a large loop because read_pixel in rdtarga.c mishandles EOF.
A crafted input file could cause a null pointer dereference in jcopy_sample_rows() when processed by libjpeg-turbo.
libjpeg-turbo 1.5.2 has a NULL Pointer Dereference in jdpostct.c and jquant1.c via a crafted JPEG file.

Libjpeg-turbo all version have a stack-based buffer overflow in the "transform" component. A remote attacker can send a malformed jpeg file to the service and cause arbitrary code execution or denial of service of the target service.

The PPM reader in libjpeg-turbo through 2.0.90 mishandles use of tjLoadImage for loading a 16-bit binary PPM file into a grayscale buffer and loading a 16-bit binary PGM file into an RGB buffer. This is related to a heap-based buffer overflow in the get_word_rgb_row function in rdppm.c.

Heap buffer overflow in libwebp in Google Chrome prior to 116.0.5845.187 and libwebp 1.3.2 allowed a remote attacker to perform an out of bounds memory write via a crafted HTML page. (Chromium security severity: Critical)

extended_information.short_description: A heap buffer overflow in libwebp may lead to remote code execution when parsing crafted images.
extended_information.full_description:
`WebP` is a modern image format developed by Google to provide superior lossless and lossy compression for images on the web. Encoding and decoding of images are done using `libwebp`, a popular library maintained by Google.

In early September 2023, a serious vulnerability tagged CVE-2023-4863 that allows attackers to cause heap overflow, leading to denial of service and perhaps remote code execution, was spotted being used in-the-wild.

Attackers can trigger the exploit by crafting a malicious `image.webp` file and finding an endpoint that parses WebP images, or even putting it on a website, as web browsers are also affected (e.g. Chrome).

A public [exploit](https://github.com/mistymntncop/CVE-2023-4863/) and [detailed technical analysis](https://blog.isosceles.com/the-webp-0day/) exists, demonstrating denial of service but no public remote code execution exploit exists. Google stated they are aware that an exploit for this CVE exists in the wild.

The linked technical write-up states that remote code execution is entirely possible due to the possibly big overflow size, but such an exploit would require a specifically engineered payload.

The `libwebp` implementation has a bug in the `ReadHuffmanCodeLengths` function in the `dec/vp8l_dec.c` module, which does not guard the Huffman table from overflow when decoding an untrusted image.

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: Exploitation of the issue is only possible when the vulnerable component is used in a specific manner. The attacker has to perform per-target research to determine the vulnerable attack vector
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description: The attacker must find an input that propagates into one of the WebP parsing functions. This could be a direct use of the library, but note that all popular web browsers are affected as well (e.g. Chrome), as they use `libwebp` to parse WebP images when browsing web pages.

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: The issue has been reported to be actively exploited in public networks
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description: Google caught an exploit for this vulnerability that was used in the wild.

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: The issue has multiple mentions in general media
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description: Articles, write-ups, and advisories were made regarding this vulnerability.

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: The issue results in a severe impact (such as remote code execution)
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description: This vulnerability causes heap overflow, which can lead to denial of service and remote code execution.

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: The issue has an exploit published
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description: A proof-of-concept and a technical write-up were published for this vulnerability.

vulnerabilities.summary: An issue was discovered IW44Image.cpp in djvulibre 3.5.28 in allows attackers to cause a denial of service via divide by zero.

DjVuLibre is a GPL implementation of DjVu, a web-centric format for distributing documents and images. Prior to version 3.5.29, the MMRDecoder::scanruns method is affected by an OOB-write vulnerability, because it does not check that the xr pointer stays within the bounds of the allocated buffer. This can lead to writes beyond the allocated memory, resulting in a heap corruption condition. An out-of-bounds read with pr is also possible for the same reason. This issue has been patched in version 3.5.29.
An issue was discovered IW44EncodeCodec.cpp in djvulibre 3.5.28 in allows attackers to cause a denial of service via divide by zero.
Under some circumstances, this weakness allows a user who has access to run the “ps” utility on a machine, the ability to write almost unlimited amounts of unfiltered data into the process heap.
linux-pam (aka Linux PAM) before 1.6.0 allows attackers to cause a denial of service (blocked login process) via mkfifo because the openat call (for protect_dir) lacks O_DIRECTORY.

A flaw was found in pam_access, where certain rules in its configuration file are mistakenly treated as hostnames. This vulnerability allows attackers to trick the system by pretending to be a trusted hostname, gaining unauthorized access. This issue poses a risk for systems that rely on this feature to control who can access certain services or terminals.

extended_information.short_description: A design problem in PAM may lead to authentication bypass by remote attackers when specific access.conf rules are defined.

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: Exploitation of the issue is only possible when the vulnerable component is used in a specific manner. The attacker has to perform per-target research to determine the vulnerable attack vector
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description:
The vulnerability only poses a risk in environments that rely on PAM's `access.conf` for local access control and contain vulnerable configurations.
A vulnerable configuration is one that uses strings which are not any of the following -
1. Hostnames (anything with a dot) 
2. ALL/LOCAL/localhost/NONE/EXCEPT 
3. IPv4 addresses or IPv6 addresses.

Example vulnerable configuration -
```
+:root:cron crond :0 tty1 tty2 tty3 tty4 tty5 tty6
```

Example non-vulnerable configuration -
```
+:root:LOCAL
```

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: The prerequisites for exploiting the issue are extremely unlikely
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description:
Exploitation of this vulnerability requires either that the attacker use DNS spoofing to fake their hostname, or that the attacker and the victim be in the same LAN. 
In addition, the attacker has to be able to log in to the relevant user (e.g. with credentials).
The vulnerability only poses a risk in environments that rely on PAM's `access.conf` for local access control.

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: The impact of exploiting the issue depends on the context of surrounding software. A severe impact such as RCE is not guaranteed.
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description: The impact of this vulnerability depends on the permissions given to the relevant user.

vulnerabilities.summary: A flaw was found in linux-pam. The pam_namespace module may improperly handle user-controlled paths, allowing local users to exploit symlink attacks and race conditions to elevate their privileges to root. This CVE provides a "complete" fix for CVE-2025-6020.

A vulnerability was found in PAM. The secret information is stored in memory, where the attacker can trigger the victim program to execute by sending characters to its standard input (stdin). As this occurs, the attacker can train the branch predictor to execute an ROP chain speculatively. This flaw could result in leaked passwords, such as those found in /etc/shadow while performing authentications.

A flaw was found in linux-pam. The module pam_namespace may use access user-controlled paths without proper protection, allowing local users to elevate their privileges to root via multiple symlink attacks and race conditions.

extended_information.short_description: Insufficient separation in `pam_namespace` may lead to local privilege escalation
extended_information.full_description:
The `pam_namespace` module is part of the Linux PAM (Pluggable Authentication Module) system. Its goal is to enhance user isolation by creating private mount namespaces for each user session. Within these namespaces, it can polyinstantiate certain directories (like `/tmp` or `$HOME`), giving each user or session a private version that’s hidden from others. This helps prevent information leaks, symlink attacks, and other types of local privilege escalation in multi-user environments.

`pam_namespace` is designed to isolate user directories using mount namespaces. However, due to incomplete protection against symlink/race condition attacks, an unprivileged user can potentially gain root access.
The attacker must be able to launch a controlled process outside of their PAM session, by doing so they will be able to alter the paths on which `pam_namespace` is operating as root.

This can allow attackers to -
1. Launch symlink attacks on a path used by `pam_namespace` during polyinstantiation setup
2. Launch race condition attacks on the security checks in `pam_namespace`
Either of these can allow the local attacker to escalate privileges to root

This is more feasible if:
1. The system has multiple users colluding with each other or-
2. PAM services are misconfigured and do not call `pam_namespace`


Examples:

1. If two users on the same system are either colluding or both compromised, one of them can tamper with the paths used to polyinstantiate directories for the other. This is possible because each user operates within their own PAM session, which places them in a separate mount namespace. As a result, the restrictions enforced by `pam_namespace` do not apply across these namespaces, allowing one user to interfere with the other's environment.

2. If a PAM service is misconfigured and fails to invoke `pam_namespace` during the creation of a new PAM session, it opens up a potential security gap. This kind of misconfiguration is not uncommon, as some packages provide PAM service files that omit the standard, distribution-provided configuration files (like `common-session` or `system-auth`).

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: Exploitation of the issue is only possible when the vulnerable component is used in a specific manner. The attacker has to perform per-target research to determine the vulnerable attack vector
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description:
To exploit this CVE, at least one of the following prerequisites must be met:

* The system has multiple users which are colluding with each other
* At least one PAM service is misconfigured and does not call `pam_namespace` when
  creating a new PAM session

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: The issue results in a severe impact (such as remote code execution)
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description: Successful exploitation allows a weak user to elevate and run anything as root.

extended_information.remediation:
##### Deployment mitigations

If `pam_namespace` is not essential for your environment, consider disabling it - this can be done by **commenting out or deleting** the following line from every file in `/etc/pam.d` -
`session required pam_namespace.so`

If `pam_namespace` is essential in your deployment, ensure it is carefully reviewed and configured to prevent it from interacting with directories or paths that unprivileged users can control, such as user home directories or world-writable locations like `/tmp`.

vulnerabilities.summary: A flaw was found in the src/list.c of tar 1.33 and earlier. This flaw allows an attacker who can submit a crafted input file to tar to cause uncontrolled consumption of memory. The highest threat from this vulnerability is to system availability.
In GNU tar before 1.35, mishandled extension attributes in a PAX archive can lead to an application crash in xheader.c.
Tar 1.15.1 does not properly warn the user when extracting setuid or setgid files, which may allow local users or remote attackers to gain privileges.

extended_information.short_description: Preserving SETUID/SETGID bits when extracting with tar may lead to privilege escalation.
extended_information.full_description:
When running as the "root" user, tar will restore by default the original permissions to any extracted files (this can be controlled via the `-p` argument). One of the restored permission bits are the SETUID/SETGID bits which make the extracted executable automatically elevate to "root" privileges, regardless of the user that ran the executable.

This behavior could be an issue when the root user extracts a crafted tar archive, which contains a SUID-enabled malicious executable, that allows privilege escalation.
De-facto, this behavior is widely known, documented and accepted behavior, and as such this issue did not receive a fix.

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: Exploiting the issue requires the user to interact with the vulnerable software
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description: A root user must extract the "affected" tar archive

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: Exploitation of the issue is only possible when the vulnerable component is used in a specific manner. The attacker has to perform per-target research to determine the vulnerable attack vector
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description: The attacker must find a vulnerability in the extracted SETUID program in order to run arbitrary code, or alternatively make the root user extract an attacker-crafted tar archive

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: The issue cannot be exploited on its own, and can only be used as part of an attack chain
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description: Simply preserving the SETUID/SETGID bits will not lead to privilege escalation. The extracted program must still have a vulnerability that will allow the unprivileged user to achieve arbitrary (local) code execution

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: The issue has been disputed by the vendor
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description: Both Red Hat and Debian security trackers disputed the issue, citing "This is the documented and expected behaviour of tar."

vulnerabilities.summary: GNU Tar through 1.34 has a one-byte out-of-bounds read that results in use of uninitialized memory for a conditional jump. Exploitation to change the flow of control has not been demonstrated. The issue occurs in from_header in list.c via a V7 archive in which mtime has approximately 11 whitespace characters.
pax_decode_header in sparse.c in GNU Tar before 1.32 had a NULL pointer dereference when parsing certain archives that have malformed extended headers.

A vulnerability was found in SQLite SQLite3 up to 3.43.0 and classified as critical. This issue affects the function sessionReadRecord of the file ext/session/sqlite3session.c of the component make alltest Handler. The manipulation leads to heap-based buffer overflow. It is recommended to apply a patch to fix this issue. The associated identifier of this vulnerability is VDB-248999.

extended_information.short_description: An out-of-bounds read in SQLite can lead to denial of service when opening a crafted database file.

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: Exploitation of the issue is only possible when the vulnerable component is used in a specific manner. The attacker has to perform per-target research to determine the vulnerable attack vector
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description:
The attackers must find a remote input that propagates to the SQLite open methods - 

* `sqlite3_open`
*  `sqlite3_open16`
* `sqlite3_open_v2`

The vulnerability can also be exploited for DoS when opening a database with the `sqlite3` command line utility, but in that case it would have no security impact (crashing a forked client process)

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: The issue has an exploit published
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description: The published PoC leads to a denial of service.

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: The prerequisites for exploiting the issue are extremely unlikely
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description: It is unlikely that an attacker will be able to supply a crafted database for the SQLite client to open.

vulnerabilities.summary: SQLite 3.30.1 mishandles certain parser-tree rewriting, related to expr.c, vdbeaux.c, and window.c. This is caused by incorrect sqlite3WindowRewrite() error handling.

There exists a vulnerability in SQLite versions before 3.50.2 where the number of aggregate terms could exceed the number of columns available. This could lead to a memory corruption issue. We recommend upgrading to version 3.50.2 or above.

A segmentation fault can occur in the sqlite3.exe command-line component of SQLite 3.36.0 via the idxGetTableInfo function when there is a crafted SQL query. NOTE: the vendor disputes the relevance of this report because a sqlite3.exe user already has full privileges (e.g., is intentionally allowed to execute commands). This report does NOT imply any problem in the SQLite library.

A Memory Leak vulnerability exists in SQLite Project SQLite3 3.35.1 and 3.37.0 via maliciously crafted SQL Queries (made via editing the Database File), it is possible to query a record, and leak subsequent bytes of memory that extend beyond the record, which could let a malicious user obtain sensitive information. NOTE: The developer disputes this as a vulnerability stating that If you give SQLite a corrupted database file and submit a query against the database, it might read parts of the database that you did not intend or expect.

In SQLite 3.44.0 through 3.49.0 before 3.49.1, the concat_ws() SQL function can cause memory to be written beyond the end of a malloc-allocated buffer. If the separator argument is attacker-controlled and has a large string (e.g., 2MB or more), an integer overflow occurs in calculating the size of the result buffer, and thus malloc may not allocate enough memory.

extended_information.short_description: A design problem in SQLite may lead to remote code execution when parsing a crafted query.
extended_information.full_description:
[SQLite](https://sqlite.org/) is a C-language library that implements a self-contained SQL database engine.

The `concat_ws()` function allows the user to concatenate numerous strings into one string, separated by a separator. It has been discovered that `concatFuncCore()`, the function responsible, contains calculations vulnerable to integer overflow. The result of these calculations is later used to determine the size of a buffer to be allocated in the heap, which is smaller than the allocated data size due to the overflow. This may lead to remote code execution or memory corruption.

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: The prerequisites for exploiting the issue are extremely unlikely
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description: To exploit this issue, attackers must find a remote input where they could control the separator and number of arguments to a `CONCAT_WS` query - which is highly unlikely.

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: The issue results in a severe impact (such as remote code execution)
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description: The impact of this vulnerability is a remote code execution.

vulnerabilities.summary: An integer overflow in the sqlite3KeyInfoFromExprList function in SQLite versions 3.39.2 through 3.41.1 allows an attacker with the ability to execute arbitrary SQL statements to cause a denial of service or disclose sensitive information from process memory via a crafted SELECT statement with a large number of expressions in the ORDER BY clause.

extended_information.short_description: Heap buffer overread in SQLite may lead to denial of service by attackers that can run arbitrary SQL SELECT queries
extended_information.full_description:
[SQLite](https://www.sqlite.org/) is a software library that provides a lightweight, self-contained, serverless, and transactional SQL database engine. It is widely used as an embedded database in various applications and devices due to its simplicity, reliability, and small footprint.
An integer overflow was found in SQLite, which leads to a heap buffer overread when executing a crafted SQL query with over 64 values in `SELECT DISTINCT` and `ORDER BY`. The heap buffer overread may lead to denial of service.

In order to exploit this issue, the attacker must be able to execute arbitrary SQL queries on the database, such as -
```
CREATE  TABLE t0 AS  SELECT  DISTINCT 0xda, 'lit0', 'lit0', 'lit0', 'lit0', 'lit0', 'lit0', 'lit0', 'lit0', 'lit0', 'lit0', 'lit0', 'lit0', 'lit0', 'lit0', 'lit0', 'lit0', 'lit0', 'lit0', 'lit0', 'lit0', 'lit0', 'lit0', 'lit0', 'lit0', 'lit0', 'lit0', 'lit0', 'lit0', 'lit0', 'lit0', 'lit0', 'lit0', 'lit0', 'lit0', 'lit0', 'lit0', 'lit0', 'lit0', 'lit0', 'lit0', 'lit0', 'lit0', 'lit0', 'lit0', 0xda-0xda-42e-300, 'lit0', 'lit0', 'lit0', 'lit0', 'lit0', 'lit0', 'lit0', 'lit0', 'lit0', 'lit0', 'lit0', 'lit0', 'lit0', 'lit0', 'lit0', 'lit0', 'lit0', 'lit0', 'lit0' ORDER  BY '%%', '%%', '%%', '%%', '%%', '%%', '%%', '%%', '%%', '%%', '%%', '%%', '%%', '%%', '%%', '%Y-%m-%d', '%%', '%%', '%%', '%%', '%%', '%%', '%%', '%%', '%%', '%%', 'lit0', '%%', '%%', '%%', '%%', '%%', '%%', '%%', '%%', '%%', '%%', '%%', '%%', '%%', 'auto', '%%', '%%', '%%', '%%', '%%', '%%', '%%', '%%', '%%', '%%', '%%', ':memory:', '%%', '%%', '%%', '%%', '%%', '%%', '%%', '%%', '%%', '%%', '';
```

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: The issue can only be exploited by an attacker with high privileges
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description: The attacker must be able to execute arbitrary SQL SELECT DISTINCT queries on the database

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: The issue is trivial to exploit and does not require a published writeup or PoC
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description: The attacker can simply execute a crafted SELECT statement with a large number of expressions in the ORDER BY clause.

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: The reported CVSS was either wrongly calculated, downgraded by other vendors, or does not reflect the vulnerability's impact
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description: The CVSS claims that no privileges are required to execute the attack. However - the attacker must be able to execute arbitrary SQL queries in order to execute the attack, which is a high privilege.

vulnerabilities.summary: SQLite before 3.32.0 allows a virtual table to be renamed to the name of one of its shadow tables, related to alter.c and build.c.
In SQLite through 3.31.1, the ALTER TABLE implementation has a use-after-free, as demonstrated by an ORDER BY clause that belongs to a compound SELECT statement.

extended_information.short_description: A use-after-free in sqlite may lead to remote code execution when executing arbitrary SQL queries.
extended_information.full_description:
The sqlite codebase contains a use-after-free issue that can be triggered via the `ALTER TABLE` SQL statement

A PoC (crashing) exploit is available as a test case [in the commit](https://www.sqlite.org/src/info/d09f8c3621d5f7f8) that resolves this issue

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: The issue can be exploited by attackers over the network
The prerequisites for exploiting the issue are extremely unlikely
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description: Attacker needs to perform arbitrary SQL queries

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: No high-impact exploit or technical writeup were published, and exploitation of the issue with high impact is either non-trivial or completely unproven
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description: Use-after-free not proven to be exploitable for RCE

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: The issue cannot result in a severe impact (such as remote code execution)
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description: The vendor classified the issue as low severity

vulnerabilities.summary: SQLite 3.30.1 mishandles certain SELECT statements with a nonexistent VIEW, leading to an application crash.
sqlite3Select in select.c in SQLite 3.30.1 allows a crash if a sub-select uses both DISTINCT and window functions, and also has certain ORDER BY usage.

In SQLite 3.49.0 before 3.49.1, certain argument values to sqlite3_db_config (in the C-language API) can cause a denial of service (application crash). An sz*nBig multiplication is not cast to a 64-bit integer, and consequently some memory allocations may be incorrect.

An integer overflow can be triggered in SQLite’s `concat_ws()` function. The resulting, truncated integer is then used to allocate a buffer. When SQLite then writes the resulting string to the buffer, it uses the original, untruncated size and thus a wild Heap Buffer overflow of size ~4GB can be triggered. This can result in arbitrary code execution.

extended_information.short_description: A design problem in SQLite may lead to remote code execution when parsing a crafted query.
extended_information.full_description:
[SQLite](https://sqlite.org/) is a C-language library that implements a self-contained SQL database engine.

The `concat_ws()` function allows the user to concatenate numerous strings into one string, separated by a separator. It has been discovered that `concatFuncCore()`, the function responsible, contains calculations vulnerable to integer overflow. The result of these calculations is later used to determine the size of a buffer to be allocated in the heap, which is smaller than the allocated data size due to the overflow. This may lead to remote code execution or memory corruption.

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: The prerequisites for exploiting the issue are extremely unlikely
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description: To exploit this issue, attackers must find a remote input where they could control the separator and number of arguments to a `CONCAT_WS` query - which is highly unlikely.

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: The issue results in a severe impact (such as remote code execution)
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description: The impact of this vulnerability is a remote code execution.

vulnerabilities.summary: SQLite 1.0.12 through 3.39.x before 3.39.2 sometimes allows an array-bounds overflow if billions of bytes are used in a string argument to a C API.

extended_information.short_description: An array out-of-bounds write in several C-API functions of SQLite could lead to code execution when passing external input to the functions.
extended_information.full_description:
[SQLite](https://www.sqlite.org/) is a database engine written in the C programming language. It is not a standalone app; rather, it is a library that software developers embed in their apps.

SQLite uses a `printf()` implementation - named `sqlite3_str_vappendf()`, for some of the C-API functions. An array out-of-bounds write based on a very large input (multi-gigabyte in input length) could theoretically lead to code execution. 
However, the vulnerable functions are not reachable via SQL queries or corrupt SQLite databases. It is only reachable through very specific C-API functions for Tree Tracing used for debugging and even so, under special conditions.

To exploit this issue, the attacker must find remote input that propagates to the C-API functions (`sqlite3_str_vappendf` / `sqlite3TreeViewLine` / `checkAppendMsg`) that trigger the vulnerability. However, it is very rare to have a published application using any of the vulnerable functions, with debugging mode enabled.

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: Exploitation of the issue is only possible when the vulnerable component is used in a specific manner. The attacker has to perform per-target research to determine the vulnerable attack vector
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description: To exploit this issue, the attacker must find remote input that propagates to the C-API functions (`sqlite3_str_vappendf` / `sqlite3TreeViewLine` / `checkAppendMsg`) that trigger the vulnerability.

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: The issue results in a severe impact (such as remote code execution)
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description: Code execution

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: The prerequisites for exploiting the issue are extremely unlikely
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description:
The prerequisites for exploitation are highly unlikely -
- The application must use the Tree Tracing feature with debugging mode enabled, which is unlikely in production applications
- The application  must forward external input to the vulnerable functions, without any bounds-checking

vulnerabilities.summary: alter.c in SQLite through 3.30.1 allows attackers to trigger infinite recursion via certain types of self-referential views in conjunction with ALTER TABLE statements.
An Invalid Pointer vulnerability exists in GNU patch 2.7 via the another_hunk function, which causes a Denial of Service.

An issue was discovered in GNU patch through 2.7.6. There is a segmentation fault, associated with a NULL pointer dereference, leading to a denial of service in the intuit_diff_type function in pch.c, aka a "mangled rename" issue.

Directory traversal vulnerability in util.c in GNU patch 2.6.1 and earlier allows user-assisted remote attackers to create or overwrite arbitrary files via a filename that is specified with a .. (dot dot) or full pathname, a related issue to CVE-2010-1679.
A double free exists in the another_hunk function in pch.c in GNU patch through 2.7.6.
Versions of the package semver before 7.5.2 are vulnerable to Regular Expression Denial of Service (ReDoS) via the function new Range, when untrusted user data is provided as a range.

extended_information.short_description: Unbounded resource consumption in the `semver` npm package could lead to denial of service via attacker-controlled input.

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: The prerequisites for exploiting the issue are either extremely common or nonexistent (always exploitable)
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description:
An attacker must find an endpoint that sends input unfiltered to the `semver` range constructor, which is highly unlikely to happen.
Another way to trigger the issue is to control the `package.json` file and make the user execute `npm install` command to trigger the vulnerability, which is more commonly used, but is dangerous by itself and leads to significant impact without the need to exploit this issue.

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: The issue cannot result in a severe impact (such as remote code execution)
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description: This vulnerability has no security impact since if an attacker can control the dependencies in the `package.json` file, then the attacker can also perform denial-of-service using a malicious dependency or inject code into the package itself, and does not need this vulnerability to achieve denial-of-service.

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: The issue has an exploit published
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description: The tests in the fix commit demonstrate denial of service.

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: The reported CVSS was either wrongly calculated, downgraded by other vendors, or does not reflect the vulnerability's impact
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description: The CVSS does not reflect the contextual prerequisites required to exploit the vulnerability.

vulnerabilities.summary:
It was discovered that dpkg-deb does not properly sanitize directory permissions when extracting a control member into a temporary directory, which is
documented as being a safe operation even on untrusted data. This may result in leaving temporary files behind on cleanup. Given automated and repeated execution of dpkg-deb commands on
adversarial .deb packages or with well compressible files, placed
inside a directory with permissions not allowing removal by a non-root
user, this can end up in a DoS scenario due to causing disk quota
exhaustion or disk full conditions.
In LibTIFF 4.0.8, there is a memory malloc failure in tif_jbig.c. A crafted TIFF document can lead to an abort resulting in a remote denial of service attack.
Lodash versions prior to 4.17.21 are vulnerable to Command Injection via the template function.

extended_information.short_description: Improper sanitization in the lodash template function leads to JavaScript code injection through the options argument.
extended_information.full_description:
JavaScript-based applications (both frontend and backend) that use the [template function](https://lodash.com/docs/4.17.15#template) -`_.template([string=''], [options={}])` from the [lodash](https://lodash.com/) utility library and provide the `options` argument (specifically the `variable` option) from untrusted user input, are vulnerable to JavaScript code injection. This issue can be easily exploited, and an exploitation example is [publicly available](https://github.com/lodash/lodash/commit/3469357cff396a26c363f8c1b5a91dde28ba4b1c#diff-a561630bb56b82342bc66697aee2ad96efddcbc9d150665abd6fb7ecb7c0ab2fR22303) in the fix tests that was introduced in version 4.17.21 - 
```js
lodash.template('', { variable: '){console.log(process.env)}; with(obj' })()
```

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: The prerequisites for exploiting the issue are extremely unlikely
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description: It is highly unlikely that a JS program will accept arbitrary remote input into the template's `options` argument

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: Exploitation of the issue is only possible when the vulnerable component is used in a specific manner. The attacker has to perform per-target research to determine the vulnerable attack vector
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description: The attacker must find remote input that propagates into the `options` argument of a `template` call

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: The issue results in a severe impact (such as remote code execution)
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description: Leads to remote code execution through JS code injection

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: The issue has an exploit published
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description: Published exploit demonstrates arbitrary JS code execution

vulnerabilities.summary: Lodash versions prior to 4.17.21 are vulnerable to Regular Expression Denial of Service (ReDoS) via the toNumber, trim and trimEnd functions.

extended_information.short_description: ReDoS in lodash could lead to a denial of service when handling untrusted strings.
extended_information.full_description:
JavaScript-based applications that use [lodash](https://github.com/lodash/lodash) and specifically the [_.toNumber](https://lodash.com/docs/4.17.15#toNumber), [_.trim](https://lodash.com/docs/4.17.15#trim) and [_.trimEnd](https://lodash.com/docs/4.17.15#trimEnd) functions, could be vulnerable to DoS (Denial of Service) through a faulty regular expression that introduces a ReDoS (Regular Expression DoS) vulnerability. This vulnerability is only triggered if untrusted user input flows into these vulnerable functions and the attacker can supply arbitrary long strings (over 50kB) that contain whitespaces. 

On a modern Core i7-based system, calling the vulnerable functions with a 50kB string could take between 2 to 3 seconds to execute and 4.5 minutes for a longer 500kB string. The fix improved the regular expression performance so it took only a few milliseconds on the same Core i7-based system. This vulnerability is easily exploitable as all is required is to build a string that triggers it as can be seen in this PoC reproducing code - 

```js
var untrusted_user_input_50k = "a" + ' '.repeat(50000) + "z"; // assume this is provided over the network
lo.trimEnd(untrusted_user_input_50k); // should take a few seconds to run
var untrusted_user_input_500k = "a" + ' '.repeat(500000) + "z"; // assume this is provided over the network
lo.trimEnd(untrusted_user_input_500k); // should take a few minutes to run
```

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: The issue has an exploit published
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description: Public exploit demonstrated ReDoS

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: Exploitation of the issue is only possible when the vulnerable component is used in a specific manner. The attacker has to perform per-target research to determine the vulnerable attack vector
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description: Exploitation depends on parsing user input by the `.toNumber`, `.trim` or `.trimEnd` `lodash` functions, and requires the input to contain whitespaces and be very long (over 50KB)

extended_information.remediation:
##### Deployment mitigations

Trim untrusted strings based on size before providing it to the vulnerable functions by using the `substring` function to with a fixed maximum size like so - ```js untrusted_user_input.substring(0, max_string_size_less_than_50kB); ```

vulnerabilities.summary: A NULL pointer dereference flaw was found in the GnuTLS software in _gnutls_figure_common_ciphersuite().

A vulnerability was found in GnuTLS. The response times to malformed ciphertexts in RSA-PSK ClientKeyExchange differ from the response times of ciphertexts with correct PKCS#1 v1.5 padding. This issue may allow a remote attacker to perform a timing side-channel attack in the RSA-PSK key exchange, potentially leading to the leakage of sensitive data. CVE-2024-0553 is designated as an incomplete resolution for CVE-2023-5981.

extended_information.short_description: A design problem in GnuTLS may lead to RSA key brute force when attackers can cause many decryption operations.

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: The issue can be exploited by attackers over the network
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description: This vulnerability does not rely on timing to exploit, but rather on the server informing the client that decryption failed, hence it can be exploited remotely, completely disregarding latency issues.

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: The reported CVSS was either wrongly calculated, downgraded by other vendors, or does not reflect the vulnerability's impact
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description: The given CVSS score does not take the context required to exploit the vulnerability into account.

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: Exploitation of the issue is only possible when the vulnerable component is used in a specific manner. The attacker has to perform per-target research to determine the vulnerable attack vector
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description:
This CVE is only exploitable when all of the following conditions are met:

1. The server must use `RSA` for key exchange.
2. The server encrypts/decrypts `RSA` with `PKCS#1 v1.5` padding.
3. The server informs the client when decryption fails.
4. An attacker is on the same subnet, hijacks a session between the client and the server and manipulates the client data.

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: The issue results in a severe impact (such as remote code execution)
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description: A successful attack would compromise the server's private RSA key, allowing the attacker to decrypt any sniffed TLS traffic sent to or from the server from any host.

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: No high-impact exploit or technical writeup were published, and exploitation of the issue with high impact is either non-trivial or completely unproven
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description: Although Bleichenbacher's Attack is well documented today, a high technical understanding of cryptography is required to exploit it.

extended_information.remediation:
##### Development mitigations

- When choosing a key exchange for your server, avoid using `RSA` and instead opt for the `Diffie-Hellman` key exchange, which provides forward secrecy.
This can be done by generating an ECDH key using OpenSSL:
`openssl ecparam -name prime256v1 -genkey -noout -out mykey-prime256v1.pem`
And giving the filepath of the keyfile to the `gnutls_certificate_set_x509_key_file` function - 
```c
gnutls_certificate_set_x509_key_file(res, certfile, "mykey-prime256v1.pem", GNUTLS_X509_FMT_PEM);
```

- When using `RSA` for key exchange, use the `OAEP` padding scheme instead of `PKCS#1 v1.5`.

- When using `RSA` and `PKCS#1` for key exchange, avoid informing the client of decryption failure.

vulnerabilities.summary: A heap-buffer-overflow (off-by-one) flaw was found in the GnuTLS software in the template parsing logic within the certtool utility. When it reads certain settings from a template file, it allows an attacker to cause an out-of-bounds (OOB) NULL pointer write, resulting in memory corruption and a denial-of-service (DoS) that could potentially crash the system.

A flaw was found in GnuTLS, which relies on libtasn1 for ASN.1 data processing. Due to an inefficient algorithm in libtasn1, decoding certain DER-encoded certificate data can take excessive time, leading to increased resource consumption. This flaw allows a remote attacker to send a specially crafted certificate, causing GnuTLS to become unresponsive or slow, resulting in a denial-of-service condition.

The SSL protocol, as used in certain configurations in Microsoft Windows and Microsoft Internet Explorer, Mozilla Firefox, Google Chrome, Opera, and other products, encrypts data by using CBC mode with chained initialization vectors, which allows man-in-the-middle attackers to obtain plaintext HTTP headers via a blockwise chosen-boundary attack (BCBA) on an HTTPS session, in conjunction with JavaScript code that uses (1) the HTML5 WebSocket API, (2) the Java URLConnection API, or (3) the Silverlight WebClient API, aka a "BEAST" attack.

A flaw was found in GnuTLS. A double-free vulnerability exists in GnuTLS due to incorrect ownership handling in the export logic of Subject Alternative Name (SAN) entries containing an otherName. If the type-id OID is invalid or malformed, GnuTLS will call asn1_delete_structure() on an ASN.1 node it does not own, leading to a double-free condition when the parent function or caller later attempts to free the same structure.

This vulnerability can be triggered using only public GnuTLS APIs and may result in denial of service or memory corruption, depending on allocator behavior.

A heap-buffer-overread vulnerability was found in GnuTLS in how it handles the Certificate Transparency (CT) Signed Certificate Timestamp (SCT) extension during X.509 certificate parsing. This flaw allows a malicious user to create a certificate containing a malformed SCT extension (OID 1.3.6.1.4.1.11129.2.4.2) that contains sensitive data. This issue leads to the exposure of confidential information when GnuTLS verifies certificates from certain websites when the certificate (SCT) is not checked correctly.
A vulnerability was found that the response times to malformed ciphertexts in RSA-PSK ClientKeyExchange differ from response times of ciphertexts with correct PKCS#1 v1.5 padding.

Multiple integer overflows in libgd in PHP before 5.2.4 allow remote attackers to cause a denial of service (application crash) and possibly execute arbitrary code via a large (1) srcW or (2) srcH value to the (a) gdImageCopyResized function, or a large (3) sy (height) or (4) sx (width) value to the (b) gdImageCreate or the (c) gdImageCreateTrueColor function.

Array index error in gd_gif_in.c in the GD Graphics Library (libgd) before 2.0.35 allows user-assisted remote attackers to cause a denial of service (crash and heap corruption) via large color index values in crafted image data, which results in a segmentation fault.

The (a) imagearc and (b) imagefilledarc functions in GD Graphics Library (libgd) before 2.0.35 allow attackers to cause a denial of service (CPU consumption) via a large (1) start or (2) end angle degree value.

The _gdGetColors function in gd_gd.c in PHP 5.2.11 and 5.3.x before 5.3.1, and the GD Graphics Library 2.x, does not properly verify a certain colorsTotal structure member, which might allow remote attackers to conduct buffer overflow or buffer over-read attacks via a crafted GD file, a different vulnerability than CVE-2009-3293. NOTE: some of these details are obtained from third party information.

An issue was discovered in disable_priv_mode in shell.c in GNU Bash through 5.0 patch 11. By default, if Bash is run with its effective UID not equal to its real UID, it will drop privileges by setting its effective UID to its real UID. However, it does so incorrectly. On Linux and other systems that support "saved UID" functionality, the saved UID is not dropped. An attacker with command execution in the shell can use "enable -f" for runtime loading of a new builtin, which can be a shared object that calls setuid() and therefore regains privileges. However, binaries running with an effective UID of 0 are unaffected.

extended_information.short_description: A logic bug in bash can lead to limited local privilege escalation.
extended_information.full_description:
Bash's privilege dropping mechanism contains a bug where permissions of non-root-SUID binaries could be restored (even after they were dropped) by invoking the shell with the `enable -f` flag, which allows loading a shared object which can call `setuid()` to restore the original UID.

This bug is extremely rare and has very little impact since non-root-SUID binaries are very rare and provide limited privilege escalation (almost all uses of SUID are with a root owner)

Fittingly, this vulnerability has been unofficially labeled "The world's least useful vulnerability"

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: The issue has an exploit published
The issue can only be exploited by an attacker that can execute code on the vulnerable machine (excluding exceedingly rare circumstances)
The prerequisites for exploiting the issue are extremely unlikely
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description: This bug is extremely rare and has very little impact since non-root-SUID binaries are very rare and provide limited privilege escalation (almost all uses of SUID are with a root owner). Fittingly, this vulnerability has been unofficially labeled "The world's least useful vulnerability"

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: The issue cannot result in a severe impact (such as remote code execution)
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description: Local privilege escalation to non-root user

vulnerabilities.summary: stress-test master commit e4c878 was discovered to contain a FPE vulnerability via the component combine_inner at /pixman-combine-float.c.

A flaw in libtasn1 causes inefficient handling of specific certificate data. When processing a large number of elements in a certificate, libtasn1 takes much longer than expected, which can slow down or even crash the system. This flaw allows an attacker to send a specially crafted certificate, causing a denial of service attack.

GNU Libtasn1-4.13 libtasn1-4.13 version libtasn1-4.13, libtasn1-4.12 contains a DoS, specifically CPU usage will reach 100% when running asn1Paser against the POC due to an issue in _asn1_expand_object_id(p_tree), after a long time, the program will be killed. This attack appears to be exploitable via parsing a crafted file.

initscripts in rPath Linux 1 sets insecure permissions for the /var/log/btmp file, which allows local users to obtain sensitive information regarding authentication attempts.  NOTE: because sshd detects the insecure permissions and does not log certain events, this also prevents sshd from logging failed authentication attempts by remote attackers.

In Shadow 4.13, it is possible to inject control characters into fields provided to the SUID program chfn (change finger). Although it is not possible to exploit this directly (e.g., adding a new user fails because \n is in the block list), it is possible to misrepresent the /etc/passwd file when viewed. Use of \r manipulations and Unicode characters to work around blocking of the : character make it possible to give the impression that a new user has been added. In other words, an adversary may be able to convince a system administrator to take the system offline (an indirect, social-engineered denial of service) by demonstrating that "cat /etc/passwd" shows a rogue user account.

shadow 4.8, in certain circumstances affecting at least Gentoo, Arch Linux, and Void Linux, allows local users to obtain root access because setuid programs are misconfigured. Specifically, this affects shadow 4.8 when compiled using --with-libpam but without explicitly passing --disable-account-tools-setuid, and without a PAM configuration suitable for use with setuid account management tools. This combination leads to account management tools (groupadd, groupdel, groupmod, useradd, userdel, usermod) that can easily be used by unprivileged local users to escalate privileges to root in multiple ways. This issue became much more relevant in approximately December 2019 when an unrelated bug was fixed (i.e., the chmod calls to suidusbins were fixed in the upstream Makefile which is now included in the release version 4.8).

shadow-utils (aka shadow) 4.4 through 4.17.0 establishes a default /etc/subuid behavior (e.g., uid 100000 through 165535 for the first user account) that can realistically conflict with the uids of users defined on locally administered networks, potentially leading to account takeover, e.g., by leveraging newuidmap for access to an NFS home directory (or same-host resources in the case of remote logins by these local network users). NOTE: it may also be argued that system administrators should not have assigned uids, within local networks, that are within the range that can occur in /etc/subuid.
shadow: TOCTOU (time-of-check time-of-use) race condition when copying and removing directory trees

A flaw was found in shadow-utils. When asking for a new password, shadow-utils asks the password twice. If the password fails on the second attempt, shadow-utils fails in cleaning the buffer used to store the first entry. This may allow an attacker with enough access to retrieve the password from the memory.

An issue was discovered in shadow 4.5. newgidmap (in shadow-utils) is setuid and allows an unprivileged user to be placed in a user namespace where setgroups(2) is permitted. This allows an attacker to remove themselves from a supplementary group, which may allow access to certain filesystem paths if the administrator has used "group blacklisting" (e.g., chmod g-rwx) to restrict access to paths. This flaw effectively reverts a security feature in the kernel (in particular, the /proc/self/setgroups knob) to prevent this sort of privilege escalation.
Libde265 v1.0.12 was discovered to contain multiple buffer overflows via the num_tile_columns and num_tile_row parameters in the function pic_parameter_set::dump.

vulnerabilities.summary: Libde265 v1.0.11 was discovered to contain a segmentation violation via the function decoder_context::process_slice_segment_header at decctx.cc.
Buffer Overflow vulnerability in libde265 v1.0.12 allows a local attacker to cause a denial of service via the allocation size exceeding the maximum supported size of 0x10000000000.
Heap Buffer Overflow vulnerability in Libde265 v1.0.15 allows attackers to crash the application via crafted payload to __interceptor_memcpy function.
Libde265 v1.0.11 was discovered to contain a heap buffer overflow via the function derive_collocated_motion_vectors at motion.cc.
Buffer Overflow vulnerability in strukturag libde265 v1.10.12 allows a local attacker to cause a denial of service via the slice_segment_header function in the slice.cc component.
Libde265 v1.0.14 was discovered to contain a heap-buffer-overflow vulnerability in the derive_spatial_luma_vector_prediction function at motion.cc.

vulnerabilities.summary: The (1) maketemp and (2) mkstemp builtin functions in GNU m4 before 1.4.11 do not quote their output when a file is created, which might allow context-dependent attackers to trigger a macro expansion, leading to unspecified use of an incorrect filename.

Unspecified vulnerability in GNU m4 before 1.4.11 might allow context-dependent attackers to execute arbitrary code, related to improper handling of filenames specified with the -F option.  NOTE: it is not clear when this issue crosses privilege boundaries.

A flaw was found in libxslt where the attribute type, atype, flags are modified in a way that corrupts internal memory management. When XSLT functions, such as the key() process, result in tree fragments, this corruption prevents the proper cleanup of ID attributes. As a result, the system may access freed memory, causing crashes or enabling attackers to trigger heap corruption.
xsltGetInheritedNsList in libxslt before 1.1.43 has a use-after-free issue related to exclusion of result prefixes.

extended_information.short_description: A use-after-free in libxslt may lead to denial of service and possibly remote code execution when parsing a stylesheet include.
extended_information.full_description:
[libxslt](https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/libxslt) is the XSLT C library developed for the GNOME project. XSLT itself is an XML-based language that defines transformations for XML documents.

All XSL style sheets are supposed to begin with one of these two (equivalent) root elements - `<xsl:stylesheet>` or `<xsl:transform>`. These root elements define the file as an XSL style sheet:
```
<xsl:stylesheet version="1.0"
xmlns:xsl="http://www.w3.org/1999/XSL/Transform">
```
or 
```
<xsl:transform version="1.0"
xmlns:xsl="http://www.w3.org/1999/XSL/Transform">
```
These root elements also set the XSLT namespace URL, which is usually `"http://www.w3.org/1999/XSL/Transform"`. This namespace URL is mostly used to define which elements serve as declarations or instructions of the XSLT language.

In general, namespaces are defined using `xmlns:{namespace}` after the element. The XSLT namespace URL is the most basic one defined in the root object, but others can be defined as well. For example:
```
<xsl:template xmlns:ns1="http://www.w3.org/url1"/>
```
This is helpful because later on, the `exclude-result-prefixes` attribute can be used to define which namespaces actually need to be included in the output XML after the transform, and which don't need to be. 

Another element that can be used is the `<xsl:include>` element. This element allows incorporating a different XSL style sheet into the current style sheet:
```
<xsl:include href="URI"/>
```
Where `URI` is the URI of the style sheet to include.

However, if a certain XSL style sheet includes another XSL style sheet, and the included style sheet has an illegal root element - such as `<xsl:text>` instead of `<xsl:stylesheet>`, and it also defines certain namespaces and adds them to the exclusion list using `exclude-result-prefixes`, all the XML nodes relating to those namespaces, including ones that hold pointers to the namespaces themselves, will be deleted - and their memory will be freed. 

However, before the nodes are freed, the pointers to the namespace URI's used in the included style sheet are saved seperately. After the deletion, these pointers are left dangling, and additional functions may try to read from them - causing a use-after-free and leading to denial of service, and possibly to remote code execution.

extended_information.short_description: An out-of-bounds read in libxml2 may lead to a denial of service when parsing XML via the python api.
extended_information.full_description:
[Libxml2](https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/libxml2/-/wikis/home) is a software library for parsing XML documents. Written in the C programming language, `libxml2` provides bindings to C++, C#, Python, Ruby, Perl, PHP, and more.

It was discovered that a miscalculation of the memory to be allocated in `xmlPythonFileRead()` and `xmlPythonFileReadRaw()` can lead to a denial-of-service attack. This is caused by Python converting text to UTF-8 bytes, causing memory allocation of up to 4 times the buffer size, resulting in a buffer overflow.

This vulnerability only affects the parsing of encoded characters via text streams using libxml's Python binding and does not affect binary streams. The official Python binding for libxml2, `lxml`, cannot be exploited as it does not allow the parsing of encoded characters in a text stream. Exploitation may be possible when manually setting libxml2 as the parser for XML processing in Python modules, which does not restrict the vulnerable encoded characters from being parsed.

extended_information.short_description: A stack buffer overflow in libxml2 may lead to remote code execution when parsing a crafted XML document with specific parser arguments.
extended_information.full_description:
[libxml2](https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/libxml2/-/wikis/home) is a software library for parsing XML documents.
Written in the C programming language, `libxml2` provides bindings to C++, C#, Python, Ruby, Perl, PHP, and more.
An `XML Document Type Definition` is a formal expression (in XML) that defines an XML document's structure, legal elements, and attributes.

It was discovered that when `libxml2` is parsing XML DTD attributes list, a stack overflow can occur. This may lead to denial of service.

To exploit this, an attacker has to send a maliciously crafted XML file to a victim service that processes XML with libxml2 (ex. by using `xmlReadFile` or `xmlParseFile`).

This issue occurs when parsing XPath elements under certain circumstances when the XML schematron has the <sch:name path="..."/> schema elements. This flaw allows a malicious actor to craft a malicious XML document used as input for libxml, resulting in the program's crash using libxml or other possible undefined behaviors.

In libxml2 before 2.13.8 and 2.14.x before 2.14.2, xmlSchemaIDCFillNodeTables in xmlschemas.c has a heap-based buffer under-read. To exploit this, a crafted XML document must be validated against an XML schema with certain identity constraints, or a crafted XML schema must be used.

extended_information.short_description: An out-of-bounds read in libxml2 may lead to a denial of service when validating a document against an XML schema.
extended_information.full_description:
[Libxml2](https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/libxml2/-/wikis/home) is an XML C parser developed for the GNOME Project.

It was discovered that insufficient checking of the `bind -> nbNodes` field in the `xmlSchemaIDCFillNodeTables()` function may result in an out-of-bound read, which in turn may lead to denial of service.

Attackers can trigger the exploit by having a specially crafted .xsd file (XML schema definition file) validated against an XML schema by one of the standard APIs, such as `xmlSchemaValidateOneElement()`, `xmlSchemaValidateFile()`, etc.

A public [proof of concept](https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/libxml2/-/issues/890) exploit exists, which demonstrates denial of service.

libxml2 through 2.11.5 has a use-after-free that can only occur after a certain memory allocation fails. This occurs in xmlUnlinkNode in tree.c. NOTE: the vendor's position is "I don't think these issues are critical enough to warrant a CVE ID ... because an attacker typically can't control when memory allocations fail."

NULL Pointer Dereference allows attackers to cause a denial of service (or application crash). This only applies when lxml is used together with libxml2 2.9.10 through 2.9.14. libxml2 2.9.9 and earlier are not affected. It allows triggering crashes through forged input data, given a vulnerable code sequence in the application. The vulnerability is caused by the iterwalk function (also used by the canonicalize function). Such code shouldn't be in wide-spread use, given that parsing + iterwalk would usually be replaced with the more efficient iterparse function. However, an XML converter that serialises to C14N would also be vulnerable, for example, and there are legitimate use cases for this code sequence. If untrusted input is received (also remotely) and processed via iterwalk function, a crash can be triggered.

extended_information.short_description: Insufficient input validation in lxml Python package leads to denial of service when parsing a crafted XML document with specific lxml functions.
extended_information.full_description:
`libxml2` is a software library for parsing XML documents.
Written in the C programming language, `libxml2` provides bindings to C++, C#, Python, Ruby, Perl, PHP, and more.

`lxml` is a Python package that makes use of `libxml2`.

`XML Namespaces` are used for providing uniquely named elements and attributes in an XML document.
When using prefixes in XML, a namespace for the prefix must be defined.

It was discovered that when parsing a valid XML root tree after parsing an incomplete XML with empty namespace definition, a NULL pointer dereference occurs.
This may lead to denial of service.

The NULL dereference happens in the `vim_appendStartNsEvents()` function defined in the `iterparse.pxi` file of `lxml`.

The vulnerability is caused by the `lxml` `iterwalk()` function (also used by the `canonicalize()` function).
There is a much more efficient and non-vulnerable function `iterparse()` that is more in use, so vulnerable usage is less common.

The root cause of this vulnerability is in `libxml2`.

A parser failure in the first run (parsing an incomplete XML with an empty namespace) had already prepared namespace information when the parsing failed, but did not get cleaned up with the normal reset of the parser context.
The second parse (of a valid XML) passed it on to the second document and `lxml` did not handle it in its code.

jfrog_research_severity_reasons.name: The prerequisites for exploiting the issue are extremely unlikely
jfrog_research_severity_reasons.description:
The attacker must find a remote service that parses user-supplied XML input and specifically calls the `canonicalize` or `iterwalk` lxml functions on the parsed XML.
Calling these functions are quite rare since `iterparse` is a much more efficient function that fulfills the same purpose.
